[Question]
i don t know how i can feel this horrible and unable to breathe so badly and this only be anxiety i genuinely feel like i m going to pas out and i have nothing to be anxious about is this really what anxiety feel like i can t take a deep breath this is so awful

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to experience such intense symptoms of anxiety, especially when it feels like you're struggling to breathe. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this and there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety.

One suggestion is to try practicing deep breathing exercises. Taking slow, deep breaths can help regulate your breathing pattern and calm your body down. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of six. Repeat this process several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Another technique you could explore is grounding yourself in the present moment. This involves focusing on your senses and bringing your attention to what you can see, hear, touch, taste, and smell in your immediate surroundings. Engaging your senses can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for stress and anxiety can be beneficial. Engaging in regular physical exercise, such as going for walks or participating in yoga classes, can help release tension and promote relaxation. Journaling your thoughts and feelings can also provide a sense of relief and clarity.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can offer support and understanding. Sometimes talking about our anxieties with someone we trust can provide a fresh perspective and alleviate some of the burden we carry.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and patience. It's essential to be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. If you continue to struggle with these symptoms, it may be helpful to seek guidance from a mental health professional who can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
no matter how hard i try i just seem to be a background character to everyone else for year i have tried to be a better person socialize more be extroverted dress nicely workout try to be friendlier love yourself yada yada yada it s all bullshit lie i told myself delusion that i thought would make me be noticed and at least somewhat respected but in the end it seems like i don t even exist it s absolutely soul crushing i feel like most people just look right through me a if i were a ghost the shadow of what once wa a person i ve never had anyone i could truly call a friend just recently my best friend told me that i wasn t even his best friend that there wa someone else that he see a his true best friend i m not angry at him just dissapointed at the circumstance i m just another shoulder to cry on for every person i talk to i ve never had a girlfriend no one ever really loved me that sting the most i constantly hear story about people and their experience with love yet here i am at 0 year old never even having kissed anyone at my age my brother already had several girlfriend so did all the other people at my age that i know i feel like a fucking clown i really am le than human i ve always been the laughingstock of the fucking world never been respected always ignored i m depressed and suicidal but most of all i m angry if people don t want to see me i will fucking force them to see me they ll have no other choice but to see me one way or another

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and disappointed about the way others perceive you. It can be disheartening to feel like you're just a background character and not truly recognized or respected. Remember, though, that everyone's journey is unique, and it's important not to compare yourself to others.

Instead of focusing on what others think of you, try redirecting your energy towards self-acceptance and self-improvement. Work on building a positive relationship with yourself by practicing self-care, engaging in activities that bring you joy, and setting realistic goals for yourself. Developing a strong sense of self-worth can positively influence how others perceive you.

When it comes to friendships, it's common for people to have different levels of closeness with others. Your best friend mentioning someone else as his true best friend doesn't diminish your worth or value as a person. Friendships often evolve naturally over time, so don't put too much pressure on yourself to find a large circle of friends immediately. Keep putting yourself out there, being open to new experiences, and eventually, you may form meaningful connections.

Regarding relationships, it's important to remember that they take time and effort from both parties involved. While it can be disheartening not to have had any romantic experiences yet, it doesn't define your worth or future prospects. Focus on personal growth, hobbies, and interests that make you happy. By investing in yourself, you'll increase your chances of finding fulfilling connections in the future.

Remember, everyone has their own struggles and insecurities, even if they don't show it. It's okay to feel angry and frustrated, but please prioritize your mental health. If you ever feel overwhelmed, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide support. Additionally, there are various online communities and forums where you can connect with people who may have similar experiences and offer understanding and encouragement.

Lastly, remember that change takes time. Be patient with yourself and keep working towards becoming the person you want to be. You deserve love, respect, and happiness, even if it doesn't always feel that way right now.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

This was particularly evident in terms of theft when people found themselves struggling with unemployment and rising costs. It's understandable that individuals who are unable to rely on support from loved ones or borrow money turn to criminal activities as a way to make ends meet or avoid falling into poverty and squalor.

While it may be difficult to provide a comprehensive response without delving deeper into the specifics of the Great Depression and its impact on society, it's important to recognize the challenges that individuals face when they are unable to find stable employment and are burdened by increasing expenses. During such times, it becomes crucial for governments and communities to come together to support those in need.

One potential approach could involve implementing policies that aim to alleviate poverty and provide assistance to those who are struggling. This might include measures such as increasing access to social safety net programs, creating job opportunities through public works projects, or providing financial aid to help cover basic necessities. Additionally, efforts could be made to address the root causes of poverty and inequality, which often contribute to criminal behavior as a last resort.

Furthermore, it would also be helpful to explore alternative solutions that focus on empowering individuals and promoting self-sufficiency. For example, providing vocational training and education programs can equip people with skills that can lead to stable employment and improve their overall economic situation. Encouraging entrepreneurship and small business development can also create opportunities for individuals to become financially independent.

In conclusion, while the Great Depression serves as a historical example, it's essential to recognize the importance of addressing present-day challenges related to poverty and unemployment. By implementing supportive policies, investing in education and training, and fostering a sense of community support, we can work towards preventing individuals from resorting to criminal activities out of necessity.

can t process this right now and i m at my wit end in the past month i ve lost my boyfriend whom i still love my old apartment and old life in oregon all of my life s worth of belonging and now my grandpa it s almost funny how insanely negative this year ha been i simply can not see myself recovering from all this loss and sadness and i don t know what to do it is just too much and i have no hope or light left i m feeling suicidal

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot this year, and I'm here to offer support. It's understandable that losing your boyfriend, your old apartment, and your life's worth of belongings has been incredibly difficult for you. Experiencing such significant losses can leave you feeling overwhelmed and hopeless.

Living with your sister, who is dealing with mental illness, addiction, depression, and borderline personality disorder, has also added to the stress and challenges you're facing. Dealing with her mood outbursts, destructive behavior, and physical attacks must be incredibly draining.

On top of all this, receiving news of your grandpa's death tonight has understandably left you reeling. Grief can be a complex and challenging emotion, especially when it comes in waves like this.

It's important to remember that you don't have to face these feelings alone. While finding a new therapist may take some time, reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support might be helpful in the meantime. They can lend an empathetic ear and provide a sense of connection during this difficult period.

Additionally, consider exploring local resources in your area that provide support groups or counseling services. These community-based organizations often offer affordable or free options that can help you navigate through this challenging time.

In the meantime, taking care of yourself is crucial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or spending time in nature, can help improve your overall well-being. Prioritizing self-care, maintaining a routine, and ensuring you get enough rest can also contribute positively to your mental health.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to allow yourself to grieve and process these losses. However, if you find that your thoughts of self-harm become more frequent or intense, please reach out to a helpline or emergency services right away. There are people who genuinely care about your well-being and want to support you through this challenging journey.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

year off and chose to stay home just so i could move out they really made sure to make me feel like shit which just made me feel like shit throughout the four year of me being in university i m supposed to be graduating in spring and i wa stupid enough to go home during the reading week which created a huge confrontation between my mother and i which my dad got involved soon after and it went downhill from there i ended up leaving early and honestly after coming back from my parent house it s like my depression went on a downward spiral i used to have a little motivation to at least do the basic thing to help myself but i literally can t bring myself to do anything schoolwork is a drag and make me hate everyone one job i work at is completely great but i have had so many bad experience with being used by employer and fake employee that i m so pessimistic when i get there and i completely separate myself from other employee my second job is even worse because while i don t want to communicate in my first job my second job no one speaks english like literally the entire store is all people from another country it s kind of ridiculous because training is non existent i literally would be standing around if it wasn t for me having past experience working in the same kind of field the employee turnover is ridiculous and the supervisor when they can communicate to me only complain about how they are only working there so because of their visa but once they are full citizen they leave the hour go by so long and working in complete silence frustrating to the point where i had to start wearing earphone while i work and listen to music anyways after typing all of this i know i won t read it over so sorry for any mistake or thing that aren t clear i think honestly i m just too pessimistic and making excuse for myself but this feeling i have in me and the way everything in life is just so upsetting the breakdown and all the fucking cry like i m so over it and i just want to either be content or at least have some kind of method to get through all of this i m so exhausted and i feel like i keep getting the short end of the stick every time

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out and shared your feelings. It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some support and guidance.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the impact of your living situation on your mental health. Living in a bedroom apartment with a dog can be challenging, especially when there are renovations going on and drilling throughout the day. This constant noise can make it difficult for you to relax or get a good night's sleep. Moving out would definitely be a consideration if it were feasible for you at the moment.

Regarding your university experience, it's understandable that feeling stuck and unsure about your path can be disheartening. It's not uncommon for plans and dreams to change along the way, and sometimes our parents' expectations can put pressure on us. Taking a year off and staying home may have given you a different perspective on moving out, which understandably created tension with your parents.

The confrontation with your mother and father must have been really difficult for you. Leaving early was a way to protect yourself from further conflict, and it's completely understandable that coming back from your parent's house had a significant impact on your motivation and overall well-being.

Working part-time jobs while attending university can provide valuable experience, but it can also be draining if you feel used or taken advantage of. The lack of communication and language barriers at your second job must be frustrating, making it challenging to connect with colleagues or feel like you're part of the team. Listening to music through earphones might help create a more tolerable environment for you.

Lastly, I want to encourage you to be kind to yourself during this challenging time. It's natural to feel pessimistic and make excuses when everything feels overwhelming. However, remember that your feelings are valid, and reaching out for support is a positive step forward.

While I'm here to listen and support you, it might also be helpful to consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and strategies to navigate through your depression. They can assist you in developing coping mechanisms and exploring ways to improve your overall well-being.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there is hope for a brighter future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms can make a significant difference in managing your anxiety. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time with loved ones, can help alleviate some of the stress and anxiety you experience. Experiment with different techniques and find what works best for you.

Building a support system is also crucial during times like these. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer understanding and support. Sometimes just talking about your feelings with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief. If you feel comfortable, consider opening up to someone close to you about what you're going through.

Lastly, practicing self-care is essential for maintaining overall well-being. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that promote self-reflection and self-compassion. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. If you find that these strategies aren't providing enough relief, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can offer personalized guidance and support.

[Question]
on the surface i can think of a lot of reason feeling ashamed about needing med worrying about side effect forgetting about them etc but at the end of the day i can t say exactly why i just know i don t want to take my med at the same time i know i need them i know that without them i simple task like showering and doing dish feel impossible i ll fall behind on my schoolwork isolated myself and sleep hour a day i know they work for me and that i ve felt much better when i wa taking them regularly but dang it i just don t want to take them one day i just ignored my alarm to take them and then i ve kept doing it now i take them so sporadically that they can t be doing much they re an ssri and mood stabilizer so they need to build up in your system and such part of me think maybe i just hate the daily reminder that i m not ok like i think that maybe if i ignore it for long enough i ll forget that i feel that way but even knowing that may be a part of it it doesn t feel like that s all there is to it and i don t know what to do about it mostly i m just wondering if anyone else feel like this too and if you do do you know why you feel that way and what may have helped you get back on track with taking them regularly i ve talked to my therapist and friend but i haven t been able to really figure out the full reason i feel this way or how to get back to taking them regularly if you ve dealt with this before or think you may understand why this resistance to taking med is happening i d appreciate hearing some potential reason or way to improve this of course everyone s mental health is unique so i may not relate to someone else s reason but i would still really appreciate hearing any potential one so i can understand my feeling about this a bit better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking support regarding your struggles with taking medication as prescribed. It can be challenging when there's resistance or difficulty sticking to a routine, but please know that you're not alone in feeling this way.

One possible reason for this resistance could be related to the fear of acknowledging your current state of mind. Sometimes, we may deny or ignore the fact that we are not okay because it can be difficult to face reality. Ignoring the reminder to take your medication might provide temporary relief, but it may also hinder your progress towards feeling better.

Another aspect to consider is the potential side effects or burdens associated with the medication. Forgetting about them or being worried about their effects can create additional stress and make it harder to follow through with taking them regularly. It might be helpful to have an open conversation with your healthcare provider about any concerns you have regarding the side effects or any other questions you may have. They can provide you with more information and possibly offer suggestions on how to manage any concerns effectively.

Additionally, exploring the underlying reasons behind your feelings of shame and reluctance can be beneficial. It's important to remember that needing medication doesn't make you weak or less than others. Everyone's journey is unique, and taking medication can be a positive step towards improving your mental well-being. Reflecting on your thoughts and emotions surrounding this issue, perhaps with the help of a therapist, might help uncover any deeper-rooted beliefs or experiences that contribute to your current feelings.

In terms of getting back on track with taking your medication regularly, finding strategies that work for you individually can be most effective. Some people find it helpful to set reminders or create a schedule that aligns with their daily routine. Others find accountability through sharing their goals with a trusted friend or family member who can check in on their progress. Exploring different approaches and finding what motivates and suits you best can increase adherence to the medication regimen.

Remember, this process takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this journey and celebrate even the small steps forward. If you continue to struggle with this resistance, it may be beneficial to discuss your specific situation with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

You've taken an important step by reaching out for support, and I commend you for that. Keep exploring and advocating for your own well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i now think about suicide constantly i feel like it is my only option in the long term i will never finish school and be able to hold down a job i will never be able to be stable enough to give my wife child i can t live up to anything anyone expects of me i am stuck though my death would be a catastrophe in my wife s life and my brother s life and i have a few friend who would be devastated a well also and i really hate to say this but the biggest reason i can t is because i can t leave my dog with anyone else he is very attached to me and no one else and would be very unhappy without me so i am stuck i can t function despite 0 year of trying medication and therapy i have no will to live except not to hurt people around me i hate this

Lastly, while it's commendable that you want to ensure the well-being of those around you, it's crucial to prioritize your own well-being as well. [Question]
no one will read this but there would be occasion i took benzodiazepine and alcohol together and had no memory for example mg ativan and a beer or beer and three ativan or beer and ativan i haven t done that in awhile issue is i am having extreme anxiety that i have ruined my brain chemical somehow like very bad and now i ve convinced myself i ve ruined my brain and i m going to be anxious forever

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to remember that I am not a mental health professional, but I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on your concerns.

Mixing benzodiazepines and alcohol can indeed have serious consequences for your health and well-being. It is not uncommon for individuals who engage in this behavior to experience blackouts or memory loss. While it may be distressing to have moments of anxiety about ruining your brain chemistry, it's essential to remind yourself that these fears are often a result of the anxiety itself rather than an accurate reflection of reality.

To address your extreme anxiety, there are several strategies you can try:

1. Mindfulness and deep breathing exercises: Engaging in mindfulness practices, such as focusing on your breath, can help ground you in the present moment and reduce anxiety.

2. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can provide a sense of release and clarity. Consider keeping a journal to express yourself and explore any underlying emotions that may be contributing to your anxiety.

3. Seeking support from loved ones: Talking to someone you trust about what you're going through can offer emotional support and reassurance. They may also be able to provide perspective and help challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs you have about your brain chemistry.

4. Self-care activities: Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate anxiety symptoms. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or practicing self-compassion through self-care rituals.

5. Educating yourself: Learning more about benzodiazepines and their effects on the brain can help dispel any misconceptions you may have. Understanding the science behind these medications can provide reassurance and help counteract any negative thoughts.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find what works best for you. If your anxiety persists or worsens, it would be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i wa just working a completely normal day in fact i felt pretty good i work at a goodwill so it s relatively social but i can handle it cause honestly every person that enters that store is fantastically polite and friendly but for some reason half way through my shift i begin getting light head i assumed it wa my tight hat or my new prescription glass so i took those off and got back to work and for a little bit actually helped but it got worse and worse my hand were shaky and i wa super light headed bless my coworkers cause i mentioned i wasn t feeling great and my manager let me have a break despite not requiring one due to shirt shift one of my coworkers actually spent a dollar to get me a snack and i wa improving i didn t wan na leave these lovely people short staffed a i wa the only product handler closing so i tried getting back on the floor and instantly i wa back in it and again bless my manager cause she suggested it wa fine and i could go home i got in my car and instantly my face felt numb by the time i wa home a relatively short drive my chest wa super numb too im i ve only ever had this feeling once before and i wa wondering if this is what a standard panic attack feel like how do i bring this up with my dad in order to get this figured out sorry if this wa long it actually helped a good bit in getting me relaxed just writing this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a really challenging experience at work, and I'm glad to hear that you were able to get some relief and support. It's important to acknowledge the symptoms you were experiencing, as they can be indicative of different conditions such as panic attacks.

To begin with, it might be helpful for you to keep track of these episodes in order to identify any patterns or triggers. By noting down when they occur and what was happening beforehand, you may start noticing any common factors that contribute to your feelings of lightheadedness, shakiness, and numbness.

When discussing this with your dad, it could be beneficial to approach the conversation from a place of curiosity rather than blame. You can let him know about your recent experiences and express your desire to understand what might be causing these episodes. Sharing specific examples, like the one you mentioned earlier, can help provide context and show him how serious you are about getting to the bottom of this.

Additionally, you can consider seeking out resources online or in books that discuss different mental health conditions, including panic attacks. Educating yourself about potential symptoms, causes, and coping strategies can empower you to better advocate for your own well-being.

Engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction can also be helpful. Some people find deep breathing exercises, meditation, or mindfulness practices beneficial in managing anxiety symptoms. Experimenting with different techniques can allow you to discover what works best for you personally.

Lastly, if you feel comfortable, you might want to reach out to a trusted friend or family member who can offer support during these episodes. Having someone understanding by your side can make a significant difference in how you feel and how effectively you can manage the situation.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it's essential to find strategies that work best for you. By taking proactive steps such as tracking your experiences, educating yourself, practicing relaxation techniques, and seeking support, you can gain valuable insights into your well-being and take positive steps towards understanding and managing any potential mental health challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i hate it i barely sleep on my weekend off day have to wake up early for work and i still feel tired usually everyday when i wake up for work i automatically have to go to the bathroom must be my anxiety because my off day i don t my work is great and i work by myself and see basically no one all 0 hour but still i won t be at home lol

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing some difficulties with your sleep and energy levels. It can be challenging to feel tired even on your days off, especially when you have to wake up early for work. I understand that this can be frustrating for you.

One suggestion I have is to establish a consistent sleep routine. Try going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, including weekends. This can help regulate your body's internal clock and improve the quality of your sleep. Additionally, creating a relaxing bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath before bed, may also promote better sleep.

Another factor that could contribute to your tiredness is dehydration. When we are dehydrated, our bodies don't function as efficiently, which can lead to fatigue. Make sure you are drinking enough water throughout the day, especially before and after work.

Regarding your anxiety, it's not uncommon to experience physical symptoms such as needing to use the bathroom more frequently. Anxiety can manifest in various ways, and it's important to find healthy coping mechanisms that work for you. Engaging in activities that help you relax and reduce stress, such as practicing deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or engaging in hobbies you enjoy, might be beneficial.

Lastly, while working by yourself can provide some solitude, it's still essential to maintain social connections. Consider reaching out to friends or loved ones during your off days to engage in activities together. Socializing and connecting with others can positively impact your mood and overall well-being.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so these suggestions may not apply to everyone. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it may be helpful to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really tough to hear that you're going through such a difficult time and feeling overwhelmed by the struggles you're facing. I can understand how frustrating it must be for you to feel like seeking help is not an option due to distance, cost, and insurance limitations.

In situations like these, it's important to remember that there are still steps you can take to support your mental well-being. While professional therapy and medication may not be readily available to you at this moment, there are alternative approaches you could consider:

1. Self-Help Resources: Exploring self-help books, online resources, or podcasts related to depression and mental health might provide some guidance and strategies to cope with your emotions.

2. Support Network: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who may be able to offer emotional support during challenging times. Sometimes talking to someone who cares about us can make a big difference.

3. Healthy Lifestyle: Engaging in regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, and ensuring sufficient sleep can positively impact your mood and overall well-being. Small changes in these areas can sometimes lead to significant improvements.

4. Mindfulness Practices: Incorporating mindfulness techniques into your daily routine, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, can help reduce stress and increase self-awareness.

5. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal can serve as a therapeutic outlet and help identify patterns or triggers that contribute to your depression.

6. Creative Outlets: Engaging in creative activities like painting, playing music, or writing can be cathartic and provide a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's essential to find what resonates with you personally. While these suggestions may not replace professional help, they can offer some support and comfort during this challenging time.

Please keep in mind that I'm here to listen and support you. If you ever need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out.

i had a meeting that i knew wa going to go well but i couldn t control my breathing and my heart rate wa insane i wa filling time with some paperwork but i couldn t focus i tried box breathing and it didn t work forgot to try grounding technique but will moving forward just to mention this pre event anxiety is normal a a kid going to birthday party made me anxious happens all the time still but this is the first time i just couldn t breathe this wa such a worrying experience i have something to actually worry about tomorrow and i hope it doesn t go the same way i honestly don t think it will because my body seems to react to adrenaline differently based on specific situation i am stressed thinking about it now or stressed because i m stressed maybe a soon a i sat down in that meeting i wa completely fine thought it might have been a combination of walking too fast and then my body not recovering from a weird breathing pattern but then i wa walking the same way later completely fine i ve been sighing all day which is what i tend to do when i am stressed i am trying to get help but yeah thing aren t moving along very well i m going to make an appointment with my therapist a soon a possible we are working together on an unrelated issue but i think we ll benefit from talking about it also worried about an upcoming wisdom teeth surgery anyway going to go cry so i can get some of this out of my system

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of anxiety lately, especially during that meeting where your body reacted strongly. It's understandable that these experiences can be worrying for you.

Firstly, it's important to remember that pre-event anxiety is actually quite common and many people go through similar experiences. You mentioned that this happens all the time, which suggests that while it may feel new and overwhelming, your body's reaction is not necessarily indicative of something more serious.

That being said, it's great that you're already thinking about seeking help from your therapist. They can provide valuable support and guidance in managing your anxiety. In addition to your appointment with them, there are some techniques you can try on your own to help manage anxiety symptoms when they arise.

One technique you mentioned trying, box breathing, didn't work for you this time. It's worth noting that different techniques work for different people, so what doesn't work one day might work another. You could try other grounding techniques, such as focusing on your senses or repeating a calming phrase to yourself, to see if they help bring your anxiety down in the moment.

Additionally, it seems like physical activity might be helpful for you. Engaging in regular exercise or even just taking short breaks throughout the day to stretch and move around can help regulate your breathing patterns and reduce anxiety.

Lastly, I understand that crying can be a way for you to release some of your emotions. It's okay to give yourself permission to feel and express your emotions in healthy ways. Whether it's through crying, journaling, or talking to someone you trust, finding outlets for your emotions can be beneficial.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so what works for others may not work exactly the same way for you. Be patient with yourself as you explore different strategies and find what works best for you. Your therapist will be able to offer personalized guidance and support as well.

made you feel bad i always wanted to be good and make you happy a a friend i never had any malice or any bad intention i never wanted to be someone who you despise this much i am just sorry and i will be really grateful if you could just let me know what i did i texted her this and and then she texted back don t say if own up to your mistake and now she will block me in text a well i am not even sure what i did and i feel depressed lonely and sad i have never felt like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and support. It's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's natural to feel hurt and confused when a friendship suddenly ends.

Firstly, take some time to reflect on your own feelings and thoughts. Understanding what happened between you and your friend can be helpful in moving forward. Consider writing down your side of the story or your feelings about the situation. This can provide clarity and give you a sense of closure, even if you don't receive a response from your friend.

Next, try to focus on self-care and building connections with others. Reach out to other people in your life who are supportive and understanding. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also help improve your mood and overall well-being.

Additionally, consider exploring new hobbies or interests that align with your values and passions. This can provide an opportunity for personal growth and self-discovery, which can positively impact your self-esteem and outlook on life.

While it's understandable that you may want a response from your friend, it's also important to respect their decision to block you. Sending them messages repeatedly may come across as desperate or needy, which could further strain the relationship. Instead, try focusing on accepting their choice and redirecting your energy towards rebuilding your own life.

Lastly, if you find yourself struggling with feelings of depression or loneliness for an extended period of time, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional. They can provide additional guidance tailored to your specific situation and help you navigate through this difficult period.

Remember, friendships can sometimes end, and it's not always within our control. By taking care of yourself, engaging in positive activities, and seeking support when needed, you can gradually heal and move forward towards building new connections.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m quitting my job today and i m a wreck this job ha great people but the work and the hour day most of the year ha pushed me deeper into my depression than i can help i feel like such a failure quitting such a prestigious job because i couldn t handle it my therapist is hyping me up and all of my friend and family are so supportive but i am so unsupportive of myself that all of it read false ha anyone quit their job before because of mental difficulty how do you get excited about new opportunity rather than feeling depressed about past challenge

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you have the support of your therapist, friends, and family as you make this decision. Quitting a job can be a significant step towards improving your mental well-being, so it's understandable that you're feeling a mix of emotions.

To help shift your mindset from feeling depressed about the past challenge to getting excited about new opportunities, here are some suggestions:

1. Reflect on your reasons: Take some time to reflect on why quitting your job is the right decision for you. Remind yourself of the negative impact it has had on your mental health and how it has exacerbated your depression. By acknowledging these factors, you can gain clarity on why leaving is beneficial for your overall well-being.

2. Set realistic expectations: It's important to set realistic expectations for yourself during this transition period. Recognize that adjusting to life without this job may take time, and it's okay to feel a range of emotions. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to grieve the loss of the position while also being open to new possibilities.

3. Focus on self-care: Use this opportunity to prioritize self-care activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Engage in hobbies, spend time with loved ones, practice mindfulness or meditation, exercise regularly, and ensure you're getting enough rest. Taking care of your physical and emotional well-being will contribute positively to your outlook on future opportunities.

4. Explore new interests: Take advantage of the extra time and energy that comes with leaving a demanding job. Consider pursuing activities or hobbies that you've always wanted to explore. This could involve learning a new skill, volunteering, taking up a creative outlet, or even starting your own business. By engaging in activities that align with your values and interests, you'll likely find a sense of fulfillment and excitement.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and there is no right or wrong way to feel about quitting your job. Give yourself permission to experience the range of emotions that come with this decision, and know that it's okay to seek support from others as you navigate this transition.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have severe anxiety and ocd and i avoided the dating scene until year ago because i honestly wanted to get over my fear and find someone i wa lucky to find a great partner and have been in a good solid relationship for six month yet somehow throughout this whole thing i ve secretly become an absolute wreck i m constantly worrying if this is the right relationship preoccupied with analyzing everything trapped in my thought and making myself utterly miserable ha anyone else experienced this like is this standard for u anxious folk or is this actually a huge red flag that dating or even this person just isn t for me thank you kindly for any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've been able to find a solid relationship after avoiding the dating scene for so long. It can be challenging to navigate relationships when dealing with severe anxiety and OCD, but it's definitely possible to make it work.

From what you've described, it seems like your worries and anxieties are quite common among anxious individuals. Many people with anxiety tend to overanalyze situations and constantly question if they're making the right choices. This can lead to a lot of distress and misery, as you've experienced.

Instead of viewing this as a red flag or an indication that dating or this person isn't for you, try to approach it as an opportunity for growth and self-reflection. Recognize that anxiety often distorts our perception of reality, making us feel more anxious than necessary.

One helpful strategy could be practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves bringing your attention to the present moment without judgment. By focusing on the here and now, you can reduce anxiety and prevent yourself from getting trapped in negative thought patterns.

Additionally, consider opening up to your partner about your struggles with anxiety and OCD. Sharing your feelings and concerns with them can help build trust and understanding within the relationship. They may also provide support and reassurance when you start doubting yourself.

Remember, relationships take time and effort from both partners. Be patient with yourself and your partner as you navigate through this journey together. Celebrate the small victories and seek professional help if needed. A therapist can provide additional guidance tailored specifically to your situation.

Overall, your experience is not unique to anxious folk, and it doesn't necessarily mean that dating or this person isn't right for you. With some self-care, mindfulness, and open communication, you can work through these challenges and continue building a healthy and fulfilling relationship.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
if it werent for him i would have been dead by now i cant imagine how horrible he would feel if i did it now im just in an eternal state of depression and cant do anything about it i both love him and hate him for it mostly love but god damn i feel trapped

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling trapped in this eternal state of depression. It can be incredibly challenging to navigate such complex emotions and the impact they have on your life. While I cannot offer professional advice, I can provide some guidance and suggestions based on my understanding of your situation.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the strength of your feelings for this person. Love and hate are powerful emotions, and experiencing them simultaneously can be overwhelming. Recognizing these conflicting emotions is a significant step towards understanding yourself better.

One suggestion I have is to consider expressing your thoughts and feelings to this individual. Openly communicating with them about how their actions have affected you may help alleviate some of the emotional burden you carry. Sharing your perspective could also lead to a deeper understanding between the two of you, fostering healing and potentially resolving some of the conflicts you feel trapped within.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your emotions might be beneficial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of relief can help improve your overall well-being. This could include hobbies, exercise, creative outlets, or even seeking support from trusted friends or family members.

Exploring self-care practices tailored to your needs might also be helpful. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally can contribute positively to your overall mood and outlook. Prioritizing sleep, maintaining a balanced diet, practicing mindfulness or meditation, and engaging in relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises can all play a role in improving your mental health.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help from a mental health expert can provide valuable support and guidance specific to your situation. They can assist you in developing coping strategies, processing your emotions, and working towards personal growth.

Please keep in mind that these suggestions are not meant to replace professional advice but rather serve as general guidance. Each individual's experience is unique, so it's essential to find what works best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i d really appreciate it here s a bit more color on the situation we were good friend started talking in december hooked up beginning of february got into a disagreement the next weekend at a bar because this girl who he had hooked up with previously wa all over him and it made me visibly very uncomfortable we spend the next week talking every day but not seeing each other i definitely try to initiate a few hangout so doe he but le so and it didn t really work i know he s also talking to other girl a well but continues to tell me that he really like me and just want to keep getting to know me better last saturday we hook up he again tell me how much he like me and that he doesnt want to play game thursday i ask him over snapchat if he want to meet up for st paddy and he doesnt answer we end up at the same bar i make a comment saying ohh i thought you said no game just teasing he get upset and think i m trying to have a feeling talk with him at a bar while he s drunk we flush it out over text the next day and i ask him if he want to hang out this weekend he say we ll see and that he ha some plan already we end up bumping into each other again on saturday this time we talk the whole afternoon but i can tell he s le flirty more withdrawn he s going to a concert so he leaf i tell him later we re all going out to this bar he like and he heart the message this morning i snap him and ask how the concert wa no response obviously i need to leave this man alone at least for a little bit but i feel like back the first time we hooked up he wa so so into me then i ruined it by being jealous at the bar and by continuing to only pursue him i got complete tunnel vision i should have just left him alone and maybe he would have come to me but now i ve put so much pressure on the situation it doesn t help that my roommate who is his friend tell me constantly how much he doesn t actually like me and that he s just a player

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot with this situationship, and I can understand how confusing and frustrating it must be for you. It's not uncommon to have feelings for someone who you've been hanging out with and hooking up with.

From what you've described, it seems like there were some positive moments between you and this guy before things started to change. The disagreement at the bar may have caused some tension between you two, which was compounded by your jealousy when he interacted with another girl. These emotions can definitely impact the dynamic of a relationship.

Continuing to pursue him despite his lack of reciprocation might have added more pressure to the situation. It's important to remember that people express interest differently, and sometimes they need their own space to process their feelings. By trying to initiate hangouts and making comments about meeting up, you may have come across as overly eager or clingy, which could have made him feel uncomfortable.

Your roommate's perspective on his feelings towards you also adds another layer of complexity. It's essential to consider different perspectives, as friends and family members often offer insights that we might overlook. However, keep in mind that they might not always have a clear understanding of the situation, and their opinions can sometimes be influenced by their own biases.

Moving forward, it would be helpful for you to take some time to reflect on your own feelings and needs. Consider whether this guy is truly aligned with what you want in a partner. Remember that rejection or a lack of interest doesn't define your worth or value as a person.

During this reflection period, focus on self-care and engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Surround yourself with supportive friends who understand and respect your emotions. Exploring new hobbies or reconnecting with old ones can help shift your attention away from this particular situation and open up new opportunities for personal growth.

When you feel ready, you can reach out to him again without putting too much pressure on the outcome. Allow things to naturally unfold and see if there is still a connection there. Remember, relationships require both parties to be actively interested and invested, so it's important not to force anything.

In the meantime, try to let go of any resentment or anger towards yourself. It's natural to make mistakes along the way, but remember that each experience helps us grow and learn more about ourselves. Be patient with yourself and embrace this opportunity for personal growth.

I hope this guidance provides some clarity and support as you navigate through this challenging situation. Remember, you are deserving of love and happiness, and there will be other opportunities for fulfilling connections in your life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
been depressed my whole life it feel like i used to have hope maybe high school wa rough but college will be my time to have fun and be happy then college wa traumatizing but i told myself thing will be better once i get a job and am done with school well guess what the time ha come and working 9 is a hell worse than all the others my whole life ha been miserable and it ha only gotten worse and worse why on earth would i believe thing will get better it ha never happened that s just on a personal level too with everything that s going on in the world environmentally politically even if i wa a mentally happy person who can honestly feel optimistic about the future of humanity after experiencing the past couple year my spirit feel truly crushed in a way i can t even describe even if i heal some of my mental illness what s the point what do i have to look forward to working til i die the thing i d do just to feel happy for one day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's tough to hear that you've been feeling depressed for your entire life and that it seems like there's been no improvement. It can be disheartening when we've lost hope and feel like our circumstances won't change. I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way, and it's important to acknowledge the challenges you've faced.

Firstly, it's understandable that college was a difficult time for you. Traumatic experiences can have a lasting impact on our mental well-being. Similarly, working a 9-5 job can be incredibly draining, especially if it's not fulfilling or enjoyable. It's completely valid to feel like things have only gotten worse over time.

However, it's crucial to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what may have worked for others might not necessarily work for you. While it may be difficult to believe that things will get better, it's essential to keep an open mind and maintain a sense of hope.

Consider exploring activities or hobbies that bring you joy or provide a sense of fulfillment. Engaging in things you enjoy can help improve your mood and overall well-being. Additionally, connecting with supportive friends or loved ones who understand and validate your feelings can make a significant difference.

In terms of the state of the world, it's natural to feel overwhelmed by the current circumstances. However, it's important to focus on what you can control within your own life. Instead of fixating on the future or the state of humanity as a whole, try redirecting your energy towards setting small achievable goals that contribute positively to your personal growth.

Remember, healing from mental illness takes time, and progress can come in small steps. It's essential to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. Celebrate even the smallest victories and seek support from professionals or trusted individuals when needed.

Lastly, it's important to recognize that while working until death may seem disheartening, it doesn't have to be the end of the story. Consider exploring new opportunities, setting long-term goals, or even reevaluating your career path to find something that brings you more fulfillment.

Please keep in mind that my response is not a substitute for professional help, but I hope these suggestions can offer some guidance and support as you navigate through this challenging time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

However, it seems like you're struggling with the realization that these distractions are only temporary and don't address the underlying issues.

Smoking again seems to be a coping mechanism for you, as it temporarily brings back some emotion. While I'm not here to judge, I would encourage you to explore healthier ways to cope with your feelings. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or practicing mindfulness techniques might help in managing your emotions more effectively.

Feeling hopeless and wanting to wither away is a difficult place to be. It's important to remember that there is always support available to you, even if it may not feel like it at the moment. Reaching out to trusted friends, family members, or seeking professional help could provide you with additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

In the meantime, it might be helpful to try journaling your thoughts and feelings. Writing can serve as an outlet for self-expression and provide clarity on what you're experiencing. Additionally, focusing on self-care practices such as getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular physical exercise can contribute positively to your overall well-being.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to take small steps forward. Be patient with yourself and celebrate any progress you make along the way. You deserve compassion and understanding throughout this process.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and expressing your feelings. It can be really tough to feel like you're missing out on social connections and worrying about saying the wrong thing. Remember, building friendships takes time and effort, and it's completely normal to have some anxiety about it.

Firstly, try not to put too much pressure on yourself. Building friendships is a two-way street, and it's important to remember that not every interaction will lead to a deep connection. Focus on enjoying the process of getting to know different people without putting all your energy into being socially "correct."

When it comes to texting back, it's okay to prioritize your own well-being. You don't have to respond immediately if you're not feeling up to it. Communicate your boundaries honestly and openly with your friends. They will appreciate your honesty and understand that you need time for yourself.

Regarding workplace friendships, it's understandable to feel anxious about saying something that might make someone hate you. Remember that everyone has different personalities and preferences, so what may seem like a misstep to one person could be perfectly fine to another. Just be yourself and let your genuine personality shine. If someone doesn't like you for who you are, then they probably weren't a good fit as a friend anyway.

As for feeling unworthy of friendship, it's important to challenge those negative thoughts. Remind yourself of your positive qualities and the value you bring to relationships. Surrounding yourself with supportive and understanding individuals can help boost your self-esteem and remind you of your worth.

Lastly, keep trying new things and putting yourself out there. It's okay if some attempts don't work out. Focus on the experiences and the growth they bring rather than solely on the outcome. Consider joining groups or activities that align with your interests, as this can provide opportunities to meet like-minded people.

Remember, building friendships takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate the small victories along the way. You deserve fulfilling connections, and I believe in your ability to find them.

 It's really important that you reach out for support right now. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time and feeling overwhelmed by negative thoughts and emotions. Remember that there is always hope and help available to you, even if it may not feel like it at the moment.

One suggestion I have is to consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide emotional support. Sometimes talking to someone who cares about us can make a big difference in how we feel. They can offer a listening ear, understanding, and possibly even some perspective on your situation.

Additionally, there are also helplines available where trained professionals can talk with you confidentially. These helplines can provide a safe space for you to express your feelings and receive guidance from people who are trained to support individuals in crisis.

Another suggestion is to engage in activities that bring you joy or give you a sense of purpose. Sometimes when we're feeling down, it can be challenging to find things to appreciate. However, trying to focus on even small moments of happiness can gradually shift our mindset. Engaging in hobbies, spending time in nature, or volunteering for a cause you care about can all contribute positively to your well-being.

Lastly, it might be helpful to explore self-help resources such as books, online articles, or podcasts that address topics like depression, self-compassion, and building resilience. While these resources cannot replace professional help, they can provide additional tools and strategies to cope with difficult emotions.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reach out for support, take small steps towards self-care, and remember that there is always the possibility of healing and growth, even when it may not seem apparent right now.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really tough to hear that you've been feeling this way for the past two years. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and support.

Firstly, it's important to remember that you're not alone in your struggles. Many people experience feelings of hopelessness and despair at times. While I may not fully understand what you're going through, I want to provide a listening ear and help you explore some possible steps forward.

One suggestion is to consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, who might be able to offer understanding and support. Opening up about your emotions and experiences can be incredibly healing and relieving. If you feel comfortable, think about who you could talk to and what you might share with them.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms can make a difference in managing your emotions. While it seems like the things you used to rely on are being taken away, there may still be other strategies you can try. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment, even if they seem small, could help improve your mood and motivation.

Exploring new hobbies or reconnecting with old interests might also be helpful in breaking out of your emotional numbness. Sometimes trying something different can reignite our passion for life.

Regarding your fear of not finding love because of how quiet and secluded you've become, it's essential to remember that love can come in various forms and from unexpected places. Focusing on self-care and self-love can play a significant role in attracting positive relationships. Taking small steps towards socializing or joining groups that align with your interests could gradually help you feel more comfortable around others.

Lastly, please keep in mind that seeking professional help from a mental health expert can provide valuable support tailored to your specific needs. They can assist you in developing coping strategies, exploring deeper issues, and guiding you towards a healthier path.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take things one step at a time. You've already shown courage by reaching out and sharing your thoughts. Keep believing in yourself, even if it feels challenging right now.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that thinking about your experiences in middle school brings up difficult emotions for you. It can be challenging to reflect on times when we feel bullied and treated poorly, especially if we wish we had handled things differently. Remember that everyone's journey is unique, and it's important not to compare yourself to others or dwell on what could have been.

Instead, try focusing on self-acceptance and self-compassion. Recognize that you were going through a tough time back then, and it's okay to feel angry and frustrated about how you were treated. Acknowledging these feelings can be a step towards healing and moving forward.

When we hold onto grudges or dwell on past injustices, they can significantly impact our mood and overall well-being. One helpful strategy might be to practice forgiveness, which doesn't mean forgetting or excusing the behavior but rather freeing yourself from the negative emotions associated with it. This process takes time and effort, so be patient with yourself.

Additionally, consider exploring healthy ways to cope with these feelings. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can help shift your focus away from negative thoughts. You may find solace in hobbies, exercise, creative outlets, or spending time with supportive friends or family members.

If anger continues to be a challenge for you, finding healthy outlets for it can also be beneficial. Expressing your emotions through journaling, talking to a trusted friend, or engaging in relaxation techniques like deep breathing or mindfulness exercises might help manage those intense feelings.

Remember, healing from past experiences is a personal journey, and progress may come in small steps. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate any positive changes, no matter how small they may seem. If you find that these emotions persist or become overwhelming, reaching out to a mental health professional could provide additional support tailored to your specific needs.

It can be really challenging to constantly feel stressed, especially when it's about school and being left out by people you thought were your friends. Remember that life is a journey, and while it may seem difficult now, there are ways to cope with these feelings.

Firstly, try reaching out to someone you trust, like a family member or another supportive person in your life. Talking to them about what you're going through can provide some relief and help you gain perspective. They might also offer guidance or suggestions on how to navigate your current situation.

Additionally, consider exploring activities or hobbies that bring you joy and allow you to express yourself. Engaging in things you enjoy can serve as a positive outlet for your emotions and help improve your overall well-being.

It might also be helpful to establish a routine that includes self-care practices. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally can make a significant difference in managing stress. This could involve getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, engaging in regular exercise, and practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or mindfulness exercises.

If you find it difficult to handle these emotions on your own, seeking support from a mental health professional could be beneficial. They can provide you with additional tools and strategies tailored to your specific needs. Remember, asking for help is not a sign of weakness but rather a courageous step towards healing and growth.

Lastly, try to remind yourself that freshman year is just the beginning, and there is still so much potential for growth and positive experiences. [Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a great time with your coworkers last night and it's understandable that waking up with some uncertainty about the day ahead can be concerning. It's natural to wonder what the plan is and reach out to someone you're closer to, like the coworker you mentioned, to see what they're up to.

From your message, it seems like there might have been a miscommunication or change of plans regarding going out for breakfast. It's possible that they may have decided to go without you for various reasons, such as wanting to have a more intimate conversation or simply because they were in a hurry that morning. It doesn't necessarily mean that you did something wrong or that they don't want to hang out with you today.

Remember, it's important not to read too much into situations without clear evidence. You mentioned that you don't have a track record of doing things out of character while drunk, which is great to hear. [Question]
im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and concerned about your health. It can be challenging to constantly think something is wrong with your brain or heart, especially when you've been to the ER twice and everything has come back normal. The tension headache you mentioned may contribute to your feelings of dizziness and make it difficult for you to move around for long periods of time.

Your high blood pressure and being on medication are important factors to consider, but it's also essential to remember that many people manage their conditions successfully. It sounds like your doctor is monitoring your situation closely, which is a positive step.

Costochondritis can cause sharp pain along the chest, but as you mentioned, your breathing and heart rate are fine. This condition tends to improve over time without any specific treatment, so it's something you can watch closely with your doctor.

Regarding the antidepressant you tried, it's not uncommon for different medications to have varying effects on individuals. Your anxiety worsening and your heart beating abnormally fast when standing up are concerns that your doctor should be aware of. By discussing these experiences, they can adjust your treatment plan accordingly.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and progress may take time. It's important to communicate openly with your doctor about your fears and concerns. They can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Lastly, while it's natural to feel scared of dying or sick of feeling this way, try to focus on the present moment. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and practicing self-care can help improve your overall well-being. Surrounding yourself with supportive friends or loved ones can also provide comfort during difficult times.

Keep in mind that seeking professional help is crucial, and this response does not replace the advice of a mental health expert.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking advice on what you're experiencing. It can be challenging to determine if if you have anxiety or ADHD, but it's important to remember that self-diagnosis is not a substitute for professional help. However, there are some steps you can take to better understand your situation and manage your symptoms.

Firstly, keeping track of your thoughts and emotions can provide valuable insights. Consider starting a journal where you record your feelings throughout the day. This can help identify patterns and triggers that may contribute to your anxiety or ADHD-like symptoms. Additionally, noting any tasks or activities that you find particularly difficult or overwhelming might give you a clearer picture of the areas where you struggle the most.

In terms of managing your nail-biting habit, it can indeed be difficult to break without outside support. One approach you could try is gradually reducing the frequency and intensity of nail-biting by using bitter-tasting nail polish or wearing gloves when you feel the urge. Over time, this may help reduce the urge to bite your nails.

Regarding your difficulty focusing, creating a structured routine can be helpful. Breaking down your tasks into smaller, manageable chunks and setting specific goals for each day can increase your motivation and productivity. Prioritizing self-care activities like exercise, getting enough sleep, and practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or mindfulness exercises can also improve your ability to focus.

When it comes to overthinking and feeling self-conscious, it's understandable that your mother's influence plays a role in how you perceive yourself. Remember that everyone has imperfections, and nobody is perfect. Challenging negative thoughts and practicing self-compassion can help counteract these self-critical tendencies. Remind yourself of your strengths and accomplishments, even if they seem small.

While seeking a diagnosis from a mental health professional can provide valuable insights, it's essential to consult with them directly. They can conduct a thorough evaluation and offer appropriate guidance based on your unique circumstances. In the meantime, exploring self-help strategies and connecting with supportive communities online or in-person may also be beneficial.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey. Many people face similar challenges, and there is support available to help you navigate through them.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with these episodes of anxiety and dissociation. It must be incredibly challenging to constantly feel disconnected from yourself and the world around you. I can understand how exhausting it is to have your body and mind in such a state.

Not being able to sleep must add to your exhaustion and frustration. When our bodies are numb and our vision is distorted, it becomes even harder to find comfort or relaxation. It's understandable that you want at least one good night's rest, as sleep deprivation can worsen anxiety symptoms.

Feeling constantly overwhelmed by anxiety and dissociation can make it seem like life never gives you a break. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this struggle, and there are steps you can take to manage your symptoms. While I'm not a professional therapist, I can offer some suggestions that may help:

1. Establish a bedtime routine: Creating a consistent routine before bed can signal to your body that it's time to wind down. This could include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing relaxation techniques.

2. Practice deep breathing exercises: Deep breathing exercises can help calm your nervous system and reduce anxiety. Try inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

3. Engage in grounding techniques: Grounding techniques can help bring you back to the present moment when dissociation takes over. One technique involves focusing on your senses - notice five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help anchor you in reality.

4. Consider journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can provide a sense of release and clarity. Try keeping a journal where you can express yourself freely without judgment. It can also be helpful to reflect on any patterns or triggers you notice in your anxiety episodes.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help, but they may offer some relief. If you feel comfortable, it could also be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
