[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this epiphany and are ready to take control of how your stutter affects you. It can be challenging when we let something define who we are, but it's never too late to make a change.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that might help you become more confident with your stutter.

One approach you could consider is practicing self-acceptance. Embrace the fact that you have a stutter and recognize that it doesn't define who you are as a person. Remind yourself of your strengths and qualities beyond your speech pattern. By accepting yourself, you may find it easier to let go of the negative self-perception and start seeing yourself in a more positive light.

Additionally, working on managing your anxiety can greatly improve your confidence and how others perceive you. Anxiety often exacerbates our stutter, making it more difficult to communicate freely. Exploring relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or even seeking support from a therapist can help reduce anxiety levels.

Another helpful strategy is to engage in activities or hobbies that allow you to express yourself in ways beyond speaking. This could include things like writing, art, music, or any other passion you may have. By showcasing your talents and interests, you provide an opportunity for others to see your worth beyond your stutter.

Lastly, connecting with supportive individuals who understand and accept you for who you are can make a significant difference. Consider joining support groups or online communities where you can share experiences, learn from others, and receive encouragement. Surrounding yourself with people who appreciate you without judgment can boost your self-confidence and help you realize that your stutter doesn't hold you back.

Remember, this process takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this journey and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve to feel confident and comfortable in your own skin, stutter and all.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m terrible at articulating my thought so apology in advance let me just say up front that no plan ha been made and despite thinking about it so much i don t think i could go through with it this is just a vent piece i guess i feel like such a burden all the time i genuinely only have one real friend left and feel like my roommate co worker hate me i m anti social and awkward i don t make eye contact and i don t talk at all ever i take way too long to text back if i did km i honestly don t think anyone would know until a body wa found or over a month had passed i m just so sick of feeling like an obstacle all the time like i m always in the way or always wrong to think feel a certain way but all of this seems pretty normal i realise it s not a healthy mindset but literally everyone on earth ha trauma everyone ha their own shit they re going through and not only doe it seem like they re handling it a lot better than me but they have real problem i have friend who lost their job over the pandemic i have friend going through break ups grief or whatever and they still manage to practice their hobby and interact with their fellow man but then there s me doing literally fucking nothing all day every day after work and having the ball to feel like shit over it a if it s out of my control i feel weak willed lazy and most of all i feel like the world s biggist egomaniac for writing so much about myself a if it needed to be said thank you for reading my aimless rambling the thought were very intrusive tonight so i just needed to self depricate i guess good night everyone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to remember that I'm here to support you, even if it feels difficult to articulate your thoughts. It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to help you find some guidance and understanding.

Firstly, please know that feeling like a burden is a common feeling for many people who are struggling with their mental health. It's not uncommon to question whether others would notice or care if you were gone. However, it's crucial to reach out and seek support when you're feeling this way. There are helplines and crisis hotlines available that can provide immediate assistance and connect you with someone who can help.

Additionally, it's understandable that feeling anti-social and awkward can make it challenging to connect with others. Remember that everyone has their own unique qualities and strengths, and it's okay to take things at your own pace. Building relationships takes time and effort, but there are also online communities and support groups where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences.

Regarding your roommate and co-worker, it's natural to feel like they hate you. Conflict and tension in relationships can be overwhelming and impact our self-esteem. However, it's important not to jump to conclusions without evidence. If possible, try having an open and honest conversation with them about how you're feeling. Sometimes, misunderstandings can be resolved through communication.

Feeling weak-willed and lazy is a common symptom of depression, and it's important to acknowledge that your mindset may not be healthy right now. While it's true that everyone has their own struggles and traumas, comparing yourself to others can be counterproductive. Each person's journey is unique, and it's essential to focus on your own healing and growth.

Lastly, self-deprecation can provide temporary relief, but it's important to challenge those negative thoughts and practice self-compassion. Remind yourself that you deserve love and care, just like anyone else. Consider exploring activities or hobbies that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment, even if they seem small.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or support hotline for assistance. They can provide the guidance and support you need to navigate through this difficult time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

for context i m an english teacher at a small private english school the school is so small i m the only teacher no sub i got my period last night and a always the first day is the worst cramp headache nausea needing the loo every minute and i feel so freaking cold today no matter what i do i just can t seem to get warm so i cancelled my two afternoon lesson and asked the receptionist to deal with a meeting with a potential client herself i mean that s pretty much her job anyway but i feel so guilty for cancelling the class the nausea got worse a soon a i sent the text to my bos i feel bad that i have to cancel two class in one day especially since i had a week holiday the week before last maybe the student are losing too much lesson time this year my class today were from to 0 and then to but i don t go home in the gap between meaning i d have to sit at my desk with nothing comfy or warm for hour all while feeling really crappy idk just looking for someone to tell me it ok to take a sick day if i need it and tell the anxiety voice to shut the heck up edit thank you so much to everyone who commented and got me through the day i went to bed feeling better emotionally and physically than when i got up today is a new day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you're feeling unwell today due to your period symptoms. It can be really challenging to teach when you're experiencing cramping, headaches, nausea, and feeling cold. Taking care of yourself is important, so I commend you for recognizing the need to cancel your afternoon lessons.

Feeling guilty about canceling classes is a common emotion, but it's important to remember that your health should always come first. You're not only responsible for your students' learning but also for your own well-being. If you continue to teach while feeling unwell, it may negatively impact both your students' experience and your own ability to perform as a teacher.

Regarding your question about taking sick days, it's great that you're seeking support and validation. While I cannot provide specific advice as a non-professional, many teachers find it helpful to establish clear policies around absences in their school or workplace. It might be worthwhile to consult your employment contract or speak with your supervisor to understand the guidelines for sick leave in your particular situation.

In the meantime, it can be beneficial to communicate openly with your students and their parents about any upcoming absences. Letting them know in advance can help manage expectations and ensure that they have alternative arrangements made if necessary. Building a strong line of communication with your students' guardians can foster trust and understanding.

Remember, you deserve support and understanding during this time. Taking care of yourself is not selfish; it's essential for maintaining your overall well-being. Focus on resting, staying hydrated, and engaging in activities that bring you comfort. Allow yourself permission to take breaks and seek assistance when needed.

Lastly, I want to acknowledge your courage in reaching out and sharing your experience. It takes strength to ask for help, and I'm glad that the support from others has helped alleviate some of your anxiety today. Remember, tomorrow is a new day, and with rest and self-care, you'll likely feel better equipped to face any challenges that come your way.

Please take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further support in the future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hello i am year old an an male i feel completly empty especally when iam in shool i laugh but i dont find the joke funny at all i just dont wan na make them feel bad but it hurt me fake laughting and when iam home i am glad that i am away from shool because for me shool is like an room where everyday it the same thing but in different subject i just feel empty thank you for reading my text sorry for my bad english

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you reached out and shared your feelings. It can be really tough to feel empty and unfulfilled, especially when you're in a situation that doesn't bring you joy or fulfillment. School can sometimes feel that way, where the routine and lack of connection can leave you feeling empty.

One suggestion I have is to try finding activities or hobbies outside of school that genuinely interest you. Engaging in something you enjoy can help fill that void and bring a sense of purpose and fulfillment. It could be anything from sports, art, music, or even exploring different clubs or groups that align with your interests.

Additionally, it might be helpful to express your feelings to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Sometimes talking about our emotions can provide relief and support. They may also offer insights or suggestions based on their own experiences.

Another idea is to explore ways to make learning more engaging for yourself. You could try setting personal goals or creating a study schedule that motivates you. Finding ways to connect with the material and make it relevant to your life can help alleviate some of the emptiness you feel during school hours.

Lastly, practicing self-care is crucial for overall well-being. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally can make a significant difference. This could include getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, engaging in relaxation techniques like deep breathing or mindfulness exercises, and finding healthy outlets for stress relief.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to experiment and find what resonates with you. If you continue to struggle with these feelings, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

[Question]
hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that seeing your current position on the leaderboard is causing you to feel anxious and stressed. It can be disheartening when our playing conditions change and we don't meet the expectations we set for ourselves. However, it's important to remember that one bad performance doesn't define your abilities or potential.

One suggestion to help calm yourself down is to focus on the process rather than solely on the results. Instead of fixating on where you end up on the leaderboard, try to enjoy the experience of competing and improving your skills. Remind yourself of the things you like about mathletics and the competition, such as the challenge or the sense of accomplishment when you perform well.

Another strategy that might be helpful is setting realistic goals for yourself. Instead of aiming for a specific position on the leaderboard, try to establish smaller, achievable targets that align with your current playing condition. This way, you can work towards gradual improvement and regain confidence in your abilities.

Additionally, it could be beneficial to explore different strategies or techniques that may enhance your performance. Consider seeking guidance from teachers, coaches, or even fellow mathletes who have experienced similar challenges. They might offer insights or suggestions that could positively impact your approach to the competitions.

Lastly, it's essential to take care of your overall well-being. Engaging in activities that promote relaxation and reduce stress can greatly contribute to your mental state. Finding healthy outlets for stress, such as exercise, hobbies, or talking to supportive friends, can help alleviate some of the pressure you're feeling.

Remember, everyone goes through ups and downs, and this setback doesn't define your worth or abilities. By focusing on the process, setting realistic goals, seeking support, and taking care of yourself, you can gradually regain your confidence and find enjoyment in participating in mathletics competitions again.

It might also be helpful to create a schedule or routine that includes dedicated time for work or other activities.

In terms of the depression you mentioned, it may be worth exploring whether therapy or counseling could be helpful for you. Speaking with a professional can provide a safe space to process your emotions, gain insights into underlying issues, and develop coping strategies tailored to your unique situation.

Lastly, finding a support system can make a significant difference in your journey towards functioning better. Connecting with friends, family, or even online communities who understand what you're going through can offer encouragement, accountability, and a sense of belonging.

Remember, everyone's experience is different, so what works for someone else may not work for you. It's important to experiment with different strategies and approaches until you find what resonates with you. You deserve to live a fulfilling life where you feel capable of taking action and achieving your goals.

my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge the symptoms you've been experiencing and how they've been affecting you. It can be challenging when memory starts to fade, weight decreases, sleep is disrupted, motivation is low, and thoughts about death become more frequent. While it's understandable that you attributed some of these symptoms to positive developments, it's crucial to consider them as potential signs of an underlying issue.

One suggestion I have is to keep track of these symptoms and any patterns or triggers you notice. By doing so, you may gain a better understanding of how they impact your daily life and identify any possible causes. Additionally, reaching out to a healthcare professional could provide valuable insights and support. They can help evaluate your symptoms in a more objective manner and offer guidance tailored to your specific situation.

In the meantime, there are also steps you can take to prioritize your mental well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can help combat feelings of emptiness and lack of motivation. It might be helpful to explore hobbies or interests that you used to enjoy but haven't pursued recently.

Establishing a routine can also be beneficial. Setting small, achievable goals each day can give you a sense of accomplishment and purpose. This could include simple tasks like going for a walk, preparing a healthy meal, or engaging in creative outlets such as writing or painting.

Regarding your thoughts about death, it's essential to remember that everyone has different ways of coping with such thoughts. Some people find it helpful to talk about their feelings with trusted friends or family members, while others prefer to express themselves through journaling or artistic expression. If these thoughts become overwhelming, it may be helpful to practice grounding techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation, to help bring yourself back to the present moment.

Lastly, I encourage you to prioritize self-care. Taking care of your physical health by maintaining a balanced diet, getting regular exercise, and ensuring adequate rest can positively impact your overall well-being.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process.

[Question]
i m starting a new job tomorrow and i m extremely anxious about it i m excited to start this new chapter but i just wish i didn t feel so nauseous right now i ve come really far in overcoming my anxiety but i ve taken everything slowly one baby step at a time this is a huge step the only job i ve had in the past year is instacarting grocery shop amp delivery that i started month ago i did everything at my own pace day a week and maybe a few order a day this job i m starting is hour shift time a week i shouldn t have set myself up for so much but i need to start working towards my career a a dog groomer and this bathing job is an incredible opportunity to do so my living situation is changing soon in that i will need to bring money to the table so i didn t have much of a choice the worst part is i can t actually bathe any dog until i ve learned from the other groomer how to do it which will take time so i worry that the day will go by really slowly because i won t even be doing anything or getting paid until i am ready to start bathing which i don t know how long that will take a friend of mine who work there in the pet store not in the grooming room pulled a lot of string for me with the bos a well my entire family and boyfriend family know i m starting tomorrow and are so happy to see me finally starting to do something meaningful they ve all had a problem with my not working for year because of my anxiety i just feel like not only for my sake but for everyone else s sake i can not screw this up i feel like i m throwing myself into the deep end and hoping i can swim

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Starting a new job can definitely be nerve-wracking, especially when it's such an important step towards your career as a dog groomer. It's completely understandable that you're feeling anxious about it, especially considering the progress you've made in overcoming your anxiety.

Taking things slowly and at your own pace is a great approach, so don't beat yourself up for taking this opportunity now. Remember that everyone starts somewhere, and it's okay to start with a basic role before moving on to more advanced tasks like bathing dogs.

It sounds like you've already taken a significant step by securing a job in the pet store, which is related to your chosen field. This shows that you're proactive and determined to make a positive change in your life. Keep reminding yourself of this when self-doubt creeps in.

Regarding feeling nauseous, it's not uncommon to experience physical symptoms of anxiety before big events. Try some relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises or engaging in activities that bring you joy and help calm your mind. Taking care of your overall well-being will greatly contribute to your success in this new role.

As for the worry that the day will go by slowly since you won't be able to start bathing dogs right away, remember that every day is an opportunity to learn and grow. Use this time to observe and learn from the other groomer. Ask questions, soak up their knowledge, and practice what you can outside of work. Before you know it, you'll be ready to start bathing dogs confidently.

Lastly, it's wonderful that you have the support of your friends, family, and boyfriend. Their encouragement can be incredibly motivating. Just remember that their expectations are not yours to carry alone. Focus on your own journey and progress, knowing that everyone makes mistakes along the way.

You've already come so far by acknowledging your fears and taking action. Trust in yourself and your ability to adapt and grow. You're not throwing yourself into the deep end; you're diving into an opportunity for personal growth and fulfillment.

Good luck with your new job, and remember to be kind to yourself throughout this process. You've got this!
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i feel like wanting to die why do i not have friend i feel soo empty lonely i mean i do have a lot of people i talk to on a daily basis but for some reason i feel the need to always have someone almost all the time with me like if i stay alone for hour i feel lonely it is weird i just wish to be happy i don t want to kill myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling this way and it's important to reach out for support. Feeling the need to always have someone with you can be a sign of loneliness, even if you have people you talk to daily. It's great that you've recognized your desire to be happy and don't want to harm yourself.

One suggestion I have is to try engaging in activities or hobbies that bring you joy and fulfillment. By pursuing things you enjoy, you may find a sense of purpose and connection that helps alleviate feelings of loneliness. Additionally, consider reaching out to local community groups or organizations related to your interests. This could provide opportunities to meet new people who share similar passions.

Another idea is to explore ways to improve your self-esteem and self-confidence. Building a positive self-image can help combat feelings of emptiness and loneliness. You might try practicing self-care regularly, setting achievable goals, or focusing on your strengths and accomplishments.

Additionally, connecting with nature can be beneficial for your mental well-being. Spending time outdoors, whether it's going for walks, hiking, or simply sitting in a park, can help reduce stress and increase overall happiness levels.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor can provide valuable guidance and support tailored specifically to your needs. They can assist you in exploring deeper underlying issues contributing to your feelings of loneliness and work with you to develop coping strategies and healing techniques.

Please keep in mind that these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help but rather serve as initial steps toward finding happiness and fulfillment.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i live at home and i love my parent but i m beginning to spiral after an incident month ago i ve been profoundly depressed and stressed out i wa renting but moved back home to save money while trying to get myself back in order especially because my med stopped working i m an only child and my parent have no friend so now that i m back home all they want to do is constantly talk to me i already have poor sleep a it is but it could be am and my dad will shake me awake to talk about a car or his work day or my mom will come in and talk to me about my finance or why i never talk to her about my mental health one time recently i had been woken up so abruptly i could feel my entire nervous system jolt like i had been struck by lighting even thinking about it make my entire body randomly hurt i never get to be alone anymore i try to get alone time but i never get it for more than a couple hour at an time bc of the sleep deprivation i hallucinate now i hear and see thing i honestly wish somthing would happen to me and it would just all end life s so stressful and the little thing aren t fun anymore i hate myself i hate everything i used to love nothing fun anymore what s the fucking point

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. It's understandable that living with your parents after the incident has been challenging for you. Feeling constantly talked to about different topics can be overwhelming, especially when you're already struggling with poor sleep and dealing with the effects of your medication not working.

Being an only child and having parents who don't have friends can make it difficult for you to have any personal space or privacy. It's important to recognize how this lack of alone time is impacting your mental health and overall well-being.

Hallucinations are a common symptom of sleep deprivation and heightened stress levels. While it may feel relieving to hear and see things, it's not a healthy coping mechanism in the long run. The fact that you're wishing something would happen to you is concerning, as it indicates the severity of your emotional distress.

Remember, you deserve support and understanding during this challenging time. It might be helpful to communicate openly with your parents about your needs and boundaries. Let them know that while you appreciate their concern, you also need some time for yourself to recharge and process your thoughts and emotions.

In addition to talking to your parents, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or someone else you feel comfortable confiding in. Having someone outside of your immediate family who can provide emotional support can make a significant difference in your well-being.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also help improve your mood. Even if everything feels pointless right now, try to identify small moments of happiness or engage in hobbies that used to bring you happiness. Sometimes, taking small steps towards self-care can have a positive impact on your overall outlook.

Lastly, please remember that there is always hope and support available. If you ever find yourself in immediate danger or unable to cope, please reach out to a helpline or emergency services right away. They can provide additional resources and guidance tailored to your specific situation.

You don't have to face this alone, and there are people who care about your well-being.

i m not the same person and i didn t like the person i wa before that so it s not even considered a loss but now i just stopped caring i genuinely stopped caring and it make me want to hate myself but the thing is im too exhausted to even hate myself i just feel like nothing just an empty space where a human used to be i ve stopped caring and it scare me i know the final step is when you stop caring and im at this step i don t care to pursue my passion or talent because whats the point why live a live when i will be forgotten why wa i even made like why even bother trying what even is the point in living if i can t be bothered to try

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling this way and it's important to acknowledge your emotions. It can be challenging when we reach a point where we stop caring about ourselves or our lives. However, remember that you are not alone in feeling this way and there are steps you can take to address these feelings.

Firstly, consider reaching out to someone you trust and feel comfortable talking to about what you're going through. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with a supportive person can provide some relief and help you gain perspective.

Additionally, self-care is crucial during times like these. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or a sense of accomplishment, even if they seem small, can help combat the feeling of emptiness. Taking care of your physical health through exercise, proper nutrition, and sufficient sleep can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

Exploring new hobbies or reconnecting with old ones might also be helpful. Engaging in activities that interest you can reignite your passion and give you a renewed sense of purpose.

Furthermore, it may be beneficial to challenge negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to your current mindset. Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts and identify patterns or triggers for negative thinking. Once identified, try replacing those negative thoughts with more positive and realistic ones.

Lastly, if you find that these feelings persist and become overwhelming, it could be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can offer additional strategies and support to help you navigate through this difficult time.

Remember, healing takes time and effort, but it's possible to regain a sense of purpose and find meaning in life again. You deserve support and care, so please don't hesitate to reach out to someone who can assist you on this journey.

 It's important to acknowledge the strength and courage it takes to reach out for support, even if you're feeling unsure or hesitant. It sounds like you've been going through a difficult time lately, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions that may be helpful to you.

Firstly, it's understandable that giving up on yourself can feel overwhelming. However, it's important to remember that everyone has their own unique journey and struggles. Instead of giving up on yourself, try focusing on small steps forward. Celebrate any progress you make, no matter how small it may seem.

Regarding your eating habits and exercise routine, it might be beneficial to start by setting realistic goals for yourself. Begin with incorporating small, nutritious meals into your day and gradually increase physical activity. Remember to be patient with yourself and not expect immediate changes. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being as well.

Managing eczema can also be challenging, but there are steps you can take to improve your skin condition. Consider researching self-care routines or speaking with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized advice. Taking care of your skin can help alleviate some of the discomfort and improve your overall sense of self-care.

While therapy may not be the right fit for everyone, it's worth exploring different options for support and healing. There are various resources available, such as online communities, support groups, or even books that can provide valuable insights and strategies for personal growth. Engaging with these resources at your own pace might give you a better understanding of what therapy entails and how it could potentially benefit you.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your emotions can be beneficial. Engaging in creative activities, journaling, or talking to a trusted friend or family member about your feelings can provide a sense of release and support. Exploring new hobbies or reconnecting with old ones might also bring a sense of fulfillment and purpose.

Lastly, it's important to remember that change takes time and setbacks are a normal part of the process. Be kind to yourself throughout this journey and celebrate any progress you make, no matter how small. You deserve support, understanding, and compassion as you navigate through these challenges.

Please keep in mind that my role here is to provide guidance and suggestions based on my own knowledge and experience, and it's important to consult with a mental health professional for personalized advice.

well i caved i cut myself for the first time today it didn t really hurt but it didn t help either i still feel like shit i can t take it anymore i switched school this year and have yet to make a single friend every day i m on the outside of the group i know that i did something to warrant this problem but no one will tell me what i did am doing i just gave up trying to nudge my way into conversation and just sit there and listen so i don t look like a lonely loser although i guess i look like one anyway anyone have any advice i need social interaction to get out of my depression also looking for new friend won t work a everyone in the grade act like i don t exist so don t suggest that

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and lonely. It can be really tough to navigate social situations, especially when it feels like you're being excluded. Remember that everyone has their own insecurities and struggles, so don't be too hard on yourself.

One suggestion I have is to try joining some clubs or activities at school that align with your interests. This can provide an opportunity to meet people who share similar hobbies or passions. Additionally, consider reaching out to classmates individually and initiating conversations. Sometimes people may not approach you first, but that doesn't mean they're uninterested in getting to know you.

Another idea is to explore other outlets for social interaction outside of school. There could be local community groups, sports teams, or volunteer organizations that align with your interests. Engaging in activities where you can connect with others who have shared values or interests can help create meaningful connections.

Additionally, remember that building friendships takes time and effort. Don't put all the pressure on yourself to make a immediate connection. Focus on being present in the moment and enjoying the experiences you participate in. By doing so, you'll increase your chances of forming genuine connections over time.

Lastly, it might be helpful to seek support from someone you trust outside of school. This could be a family member, teacher, or counselor who can offer guidance and encouragement. They can also provide a listening ear if you need to vent about your experiences.

Remember, you deserve to have fulfilling social connections and support. Keep trying different approaches, stay open-minded, and be patient with yourself.

i already called in yesterday for work i wa up all night laying here just awake counting down the hour to work wa so exhausted by the time work came around that i called in and even then i couldn t sleep it s now 0 pm and i ve gotten under an hour of sleep in the last 0 hr i m starting to worry a bit this month ha been so hard for me i literally almost walked into traffic on the way to work last week been cry so much i m so alone and it really scare me because i m going through all of this by myself

 It sounds like you've been going through a really tough time lately. It's understandable that not getting enough sleep can make you feel exhausted and worried. I'm here to offer some guidance and support for what you're experiencing.

Firstly, it's important to prioritize your well-being. If you're feeling so tired and overwhelmed, it might be helpful to take a break from work or seek assistance from your employer regarding your absence. Taking care of yourself should always come first.

Counting down the hours until work can add unnecessary stress to an already difficult situation. It might be beneficial to establish a bedtime routine that promotes relaxation and ensures you get enough rest. Creating a calming environment before bed, such as dimming lights or engaging in soothing activities like reading or taking a warm bath, could potentially help improve your sleep patterns.

Feeling exhausted and unable to sleep can often exacerbate emotions, making it harder to cope with daily challenges. It's completely normal to feel scared and alone during times like these. However, remember that you don't have to face everything by yourself. Reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support can make a significant difference. Sometimes just talking to someone who cares can alleviate some of the burden you're carrying.

Additionally, consider exploring self-help strategies that may assist you in managing stress and improving mood. Engaging in regular physical exercise, practicing mindfulness or deep breathing exercises, and finding enjoyable activities that bring you a sense of fulfillment can all contribute positively to your mental well-being.

While I'm not a mental health professional, I genuinely hope these suggestions can provide some assistance and comfort during this challenging period. Remember, seeking professional help from a licensed therapist or counselor can also be beneficial if you continue to struggle with these feelings. They can offer personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. It's understandable that losing your independence and moving back in with your mother is causing a lot of stress and frustration for you. Feeling trapped and controlled can be incredibly difficult to deal with, especially when you're already struggling with depression and suicidal thoughts.

I want to first acknowledge your feelings and validate your experience. It's not fair to have your hopes raised only to have them taken away again. Moving back in with your mother may bring about a sense of stability, but it also means giving up some of your autonomy and facing challenges you may not have anticipated.

It's important to remember that you deserve support and understanding during this challenging time. While it may feel overwhelming, try to find healthy ways to express your emotions and concerns to your mother. Openly communicating with her about how you're feeling and what you need from her support can help set boundaries and manage expectations.

Additionally, reaching out to a trusted friend or someone else who can provide emotional support outside of your living situation might be beneficial. Having someone to talk to and lean on during this transition period could make a significant difference in your well-being.

Regarding your motivation, it's common for depression to impact our drive and energy levels. However, finding small steps that you can take each day towards self-care and personal growth can gradually improve your motivation. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment, even if they seem insignificant at first, can make a positive impact on your mood and mindset.

Lastly, please consider seeking professional help if you haven't already. A mental health therapist or counselor can offer guidance tailored to your specific needs and circumstances. They can assist you in navigating these challenges, developing coping strategies, and exploring potential options for your future.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. There are resources available to support you, and it's important to reach out and utilize them.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also be helpful. Think about hobbies or interests that make you feel happy and engaged. Doing something enjoyable can uplift your mood and provide a temporary distraction from negative thoughts.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. [Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and anxious after experiencing such difficult losses in your family. Grief can be a challenging journey, especially when it affects multiple members of your family. 

To help calm yourself and center yourself during this time, there are some strategies you can try:

1. Deep Breathing: Taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce anxiety. Try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of six. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

2. Grounding Techniques: When you're feeling outside of your comfort zone, grounding techniques can help bring you back to the present moment. One technique is to focus on your senses. Take a moment to notice five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help anchor you in the present and provide a sense of stability.

3. Self-Care: Taking care of yourself is crucial during times of heightened anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Consider incorporating activities like exercise, journaling, listening to calming music, or spending time in nature into your routine.

4. Seeking Support: It's important to remember that you don't have to navigate through this difficult time alone. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer support and understanding. Sometimes talking about your feelings with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief.

5. Mindfulness Practices: Practicing mindfulness can help you stay present and reduce anxiety. You can try guided meditation or simply focus on your breath for a few minutes each day. By observing your thoughts and emotions without judgment, you can cultivate a greater sense of calmness and acceptance.

Remember, everyone's experience with grief is unique, so it's important to be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through this challenging time. If your anxiety persists or worsens, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Family history can indeed play a role in certain health conditions, including heart disease. However, without a definitive diagnosis, it would be unwise to assume that you have inherited this particular disease. This could involve discussing with other family members who may have experienced similar symptoms or been diagnosed with heart disease. Sharing this information with a healthcare professional can assist them in understanding your family's background better and guiding you accordingly.

In the meantime, there are steps you can take to promote your overall cardiovascular health. Engaging in regular physical activity, maintaining a balanced diet, and avoiding smoking can positively impact your heart's well-being. Additionally, practicing stress management techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation can also contribute to your overall mental and physical health.

Remember, while self-diagnosis can lead to unnecessary worry, reaching out to a healthcare professional will provide you with the support and guidance needed to navigate your situation effectively. wa doing so we hopped on this facetime call and had a really nice long conversation about all the stuff we had to catch up on and then after an hour i switched the topic back to our relationship and she basically said that she didn t feel the same way i wa so hurt when she said this because all the sign pointed to her liking me too and i really felt like i knew what her heart wa saying we both went to sleep cry that night for each other the next day i sent her a text this time saying that i do need some space to figure thing out and we can talk after spring break so for the next week we didn t talk she didn t view my story like any of my social medium post and just simply didn t communicate with each other and it wa one of the worst thing for me to go through a she wa someone i isn t true and i told her that i didn t which is true there were rumor going around about u from people that saw u hangout a lot that saw u embrace at the bar that saw u kiss at the club and saw u walk back to my apartment together so people could only assume that we were a thing and i kept telling her that but she wasn t having it she facetimed me saying that she regretted ever kissing me she text explaining that i never said anything that i really cared about her and just wanted my best friend back she responded by saying that she appreciated me reaching out and that she wa over the in person and just talk she responded back by saying that she s potentially open to it but not now maybe next week so i said i just genuinely need someone to talk to but i understand her the last text she sent me wa i don t think i can be that person for you anymore i m sorry i am heartbroken devastated and hopeless angry at myself angry at this world and i just want to leave i have no direction in life no one to turn to anymore and i just want to end it all a soon a possible

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and support. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way.

Firstly, it's understandable that failing your college class and having a strained relationship with your parents is causing you to feel discouraged. These challenges can make it difficult to see a clear path forward. However, please know that there are resources available to help you improve your academic performance and mend your relationships. Consider reaching out to your professors or academic advisors for assistance with your coursework, and perhaps explore counseling services at your college to address the issues with your parents.

Regarding the organization you mentioned, it's unfortunate that things didn't work out as expected. Being accused of things that aren't true can be incredibly frustrating and disheartening. While it may be helpful to seek clarification about the accusations and try to resolve the situation, it's also important to acknowledge that sometimes conflicts happen, and it's okay to part ways. Use this experience as an opportunity for personal growth and to focus on other areas of your life that bring you joy and fulfillment.

When it comes to your feelings for this woman, it's clear that she holds a significant place in your heart. Opening up to someone about your feelings can be vulnerable, and it's completely normal to experience mixed emotions afterward. Her reaction caught you off guard, and it's natural to feel hurt and confused. Give yourself time to process these feelings without judgment. Remember that her decision not to pursue a romantic relationship with you doesn't invalidate the deep bond you shared as friends. Continue reaching out to her when you feel ready, but also allow yourself space to heal and move forward.

Feeling hopeless and wanting to end it all is a heavy burden to carry. Please know that there is always hope, even when it feels distant. Reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes talking to someone who cares about us can provide the support we need to keep moving forward. Additionally, consider exploring mental health resources available on campus or in your community. They can offer guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, you are not defined by this difficult period in your life. It may take time, but with resilience and support, you can find direction, purpose, and a sense of belonging again. Keep reaching out for help when you need it, and remember that there are people who care about you and want to see you thrive.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge and address the emotions you're experiencing. It can be challenging when we feel stuck in a difficult situation, like the one you described. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your thoughts and feelings without judgment. Understanding yourself better can provide valuable insights into why you might be feeling this way.

2. Seek support: Consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can offer a listening ear and support. Sometimes talking about our experiences with someone we trust can bring relief and perspective.

3. Healthy coping mechanisms: Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help improve your mood and overall well-being. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or practicing mindfulness techniques.

4. Setting realistic goals: Break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps to avoid feeling overwhelmed. Celebrate small achievements along the way to boost your motivation and sense of accomplishment.

5. Prioritizing self-care: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that promote self-care and rejuvenation.

6. Exploring professional help options: If you find that your symptoms persist or worsen over time, it may be beneficial to consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist or counselor. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and circumstances.

7. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal can be a helpful tool for processing emotions and gaining clarity. It allows you to express yourself freely without any judgment.

8. Connecting with others who have been through similar experiences: Consider joining support groups or online communities where individuals share similar struggles. Sharing stories and learning from others who have overcome challenges can be inspiring and empowering.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and progress takes time. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest steps forward. You deserve happiness and fulfillment in your life.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really important that you reach out for support, especially when you're feeling this way. Remember that there is always hope and help available to you. Here are some suggestions:

1. Reach out to a trusted friend or family member: Share what you're going through with someone who cares about you. Opening up to them can provide a sense of relief and they may be able to offer the support you need.

2. Consider seeking professional help: A mental health professional can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore coping strategies, identify underlying issues, and develop a personalized plan for recovery.

3. Connect with a helpline or crisis hotline: These services are designed to provide immediate assistance to individuals in distress. They have trained professionals available 24/7 who can listen, offer support, and connect you with additional resources.

4. Engage in self-care activities: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial during difficult times. Find activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, hobbies, mindfulness practices, or spending time in nature.

5. Build a support network: Surround yourself with positive influences and supportive people who uplift you. Consider joining support groups or online communities where you can connect with others who may be going through similar experiences.

6. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize that the negative thoughts you have about yourself are not necessarily true. Practice self-compassion and remind yourself of your strengths and accomplishments. It can also be helpful to write down positive affirmations or quotes to refer to during moments of self-doubt.

7. Create a safety plan: Develop a plan for managing crises or moments when you feel overwhelmed. This could include having a list of emergency contacts, engaging in distraction techniques (e.g., listening to music, reading, or going for a walk), or practicing deep breathing exercises.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. There is support available to you, and by reaching out and seeking help, you are taking an important step towards healing and recovery.

i have been away from home for week and yesterday i wa scheduled to return my friend had offered to pick me up from the airport for context i don t live in the safest city for woman after i land my friend text me saying they can t pick me up from the airport and i should book a cab and come home i wa at the airport from pm to am because there were no cab available creepy men started following me stating oh no one s here to pick you up i had to go to the police because the men didn t stop following me i had a breakdown in public and i couldn t breathe i finally called a friend who life near by who came to pick me up at around 0 am by then i wa completely wrecked yesterday wa a complete mess and im still feeling anxious and triggered

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling anxious and triggered after the experience you had at the airport. It must have been really difficult for you to deal with those creepy men following you and not being able to find a cab. I'm glad your friend who lives nearby was able to come and help you in the end.

Safety is definitely a concern, especially when traveling as a woman. It can be overwhelming and scary when things don't go as planned. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being in situations like these. 

One suggestion I have is to consider using a ride-sharing service or booking a taxi in advance if you know you'll be arriving at the airport late at night. This way, you can ensure that transportation will be available for you when you land. Additionally, it might be helpful to let someone you trust know your travel plans and expected arrival time so they can keep an eye out for any issues.

Another suggestion is to familiarize yourself with the resources available at the airport. Many airports have information desks or security personnel who can assist you if you feel unsafe or unsure about anything. They may be able to provide guidance on local transportation options or even call a cab for you.

Lastly, self-defense classes or apps that offer emergency services could also be beneficial for your peace of mind. Learning some basic self-defense techniques can empower you to protect yourself if needed. There are various apps available that connect you with emergency services or provide GPS tracking in case of an emergency.

Remember, your safety should always be a priority. By taking some precautions and having a support system in place, you can feel more secure when traveling alone.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really tough to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, even if it feels like there aren't many resources or help available in your small town. There are several steps you can take to seek support and prioritize your mental health.

Firstly, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Opening up about what you're going through can provide a sense of relief and support. They may be able to offer guidance or connect you with someone who can assist you further.

Additionally, you might want to explore online communities or forums where individuals facing similar challenges come together to share their experiences and coping strategies. Engaging with these communities could help you find additional support and gain insights into managing depression.

Another option is to try and find local support groups or organizations that specialize in mental health. While it may require some research, there might be groups that meet regularly or offer workshops or counseling services. Connecting with others who understand firsthand what you're experiencing can be incredibly valuable.

In terms of self-harm and suicidal thoughts, it's crucial to have a plan in place for when you feel overwhelmed. Reach out to a crisis hotline or helpline that operates 24/7. These services employ trained professionals who can listen to you, offer support, and connect you with appropriate resources in your area.

Lastly, please know that there is always hope, even when it may seem distant. Consider exploring different self-help techniques, such as mindfulness exercises, journaling, or engaging in activities that bring you joy. Taking small steps towards self-care can make a significant difference in managing depressive symptoms.

Remember, seeking help takes courage, and you deserve support and understanding. You are deserving of a life free from the burden of depression. Keep reaching out and advocating for yourself – you matter, and your feelings are valid.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i don t feel like myself anymore and i don t think i can be fixed not a day go by where i wish i didn t wake up again i don t know what s wrong and i ve been trying so hard to be better i just can t do it anymore i m so sorry

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling this way and it's important to acknowledge your emotions. It can be really challenging when we start to question our own identity and feel like we're not ourselves anymore. Feeling this way consistently suggests that there may be something deeper going on, and it's commendable that you've been trying so hard to improve.

While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my understanding. One possibility could be exploring different aspects of your life that might be contributing to these feelings. Reflecting on relationships, work or school, hobbies, and any major life changes can help shed light on potential triggers or sources of stress.

Additionally, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, who can provide support and a listening ear. Sometimes talking about our thoughts and feelings with someone who cares can make a significant difference. They may also be able to offer insights or perspectives that you haven't considered before.

Engaging in self-care activities can also be helpful. Taking care of your physical health through exercise, proper nutrition, and sufficient sleep can positively impact your mental well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as reading, spending time in nature, or practicing mindfulness techniques, can also contribute to your overall mood.

Lastly, if these feelings persist and become overwhelming, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can provide a more comprehensive evaluation and guide you towards appropriate resources or therapies that could assist you on your journey toward healing and self-discovery.

Remember, you are not alone in this, and there is hope for improvement. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to feel whatever emotions arise without judgment. You deserve support and understanding as you navigate through this challenging time.

[Question]
im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about what you're experiencing. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of emotions and thoughts, especially when it comes to motherhood and the responsibilities that come with it. Remember that being a parent is a journey filled with ups and downs, and it's normal to have moments of doubt or feeling like you're not doing enough.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that having intrusive thoughts can be really challenging and distressing. However, having those thoughts doesn't necessarily mean you have postpartum OCD (PPocd). It might be helpful for you to explore these thoughts further with a mental health professional who can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific situation.

In the meantime, there are some strategies you can try to help manage those intrusive thoughts. One approach is grounding yourself in the present moment by focusing on your senses or engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation. This can help redirect your attention away from those overwhelming thoughts.

Additionally, reaching out for support is crucial during this time. Consider talking to your partner about how you're feeling, as he may be able to offer understanding and assistance. Building a strong support system can make a significant difference in managing stress and feeling less alone.

Regarding your guilt about others watching your son, it's common to want to take care of your child yourself. However, recognizing that asking for help is not a sign of weakness but rather a way to ensure both you and your child receive the support you need. Taking breaks and allowing others to assist you can actually contribute positively to your well-being and enable you to be a more present and effective parent in the long run.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help is always an option. A mental health therapist can provide valuable insights and techniques to help you navigate through these challenging thoughts and emotions. They can work with you to develop coping strategies and explore any underlying issues that may be contributing to your feelings of being overwhelmed.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. It's important to be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through these difficulties.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

also i can t even look nobody in the eye because of it wtf do i do it s ruining the relationship i have with my family and parent it s just pissing me tf off i went to get a haircut today but walked tf out because i wa too anxious and my anxiety wa high so when i walked in i sat all the way in the back so my barber and other people wouldn t see me because of my dumbass anxiety but how else wa i gon na get a cut if he couldn t see me right so like i said i just walked tf out with my head down n cried when i got home

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with your alopecia and it's affecting your relationships and causing a lot of anxiety for you. I can imagine how difficult it must be to deal with this on a daily basis.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from others who may understand what you're going through. There are online communities or support groups where individuals with alopecia come together to share their experiences and offer advice. Connecting with people who have similar struggles might provide you with some comfort and helpful insights.

Additionally, finding ways to manage your anxiety could greatly improve your situation. It's understandable that the fear of judgment or staring from others makes it challenging for you to engage in social situations. One technique that might help is deep breathing exercises. When you feel anxious, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your nervous system and reduce anxiety symptoms.

Regarding getting a haircut, there are a few options you could explore. One possibility is finding a barber who specializes in serving clients with alopecia or has experience cutting hair for individuals with different hair types. You could reach out to local salons and ask if they have any recommendations. Another option is to ask a trusted friend or family member to accompany you during your haircut appointment, providing support and reassurance.

Remember, it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. Accepting and embracing our own identities can take time, especially when faced with societal pressures. Surround yourself with understanding and supportive individuals who appreciate you for who you are.

Lastly, if you find that your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can work with you to develop coping strategies and explore additional treatment options that may be available.

Please know that you are not alone in this journey, and there are resources and people who can help you navigate through these challenges.

[Question]
it s been year of fighting with my brain everyday i last attempted a month ago and it wa honestly traumatizing i know it s only a waiting game till i give up again i m just sick of failed attempt and it s the only reason i m putting it off i m so over everything i didn t go to therapy this week because i couldn t face having to talk i feel so broken and unable to deal with anything and idk what to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling exhausted and fed up with the constant struggle with your brain. Going through a difficult experience like a suicide attempt can be traumatic, and it's natural to feel overwhelmed and drained by it. The fact that you're still reaching out for support shows a lot of strength and resilience.

Feeling sick of failed attempts is a common emotion, but please remember that each attempt is unique, and there are many factors that come into play. It's important not to lose hope or give up just yet. There are still options available to explore and strategies to try.

Putting things off and avoiding therapy is also a common response when we're feeling overwhelmed or anxious about facing certain challenges. However, therapy can provide valuable tools and support to help you navigate through this difficult time. If you're unable to face going to therapy physically, there may be remote options available, such as online sessions or phone counseling. Exploring these alternatives might make it more accessible for you to receive the help you need.

Feeling broken and unable to deal with anything is a sign that you may need additional support. Alongside therapy, there are other coping mechanisms you can try to help manage your emotions. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, practicing mindfulness or deep breathing exercises, reaching out to trusted friends or family members, or even journaling your thoughts and feelings can all be helpful strategies.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. You deserve support and understanding, so don't hesitate to reach out to someone who can provide a listening ear or professional guidance. You are not alone in this journey, and there is hope for brighter days ahead.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out for support, even if it feels like the wrong subreddit. It can be really challenging when we have what we want but start to question if it's what we truly desired. Your past experiences with a suicidal friend seem to have had a significant impact on your perspective on life.

Losing motivation and having no goals or dreams anymore can be incredibly difficult to cope with. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that might help you regain your energy and find a more positive outlook on life:

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your values, interests, and passions. What used to bring you joy? Exploring these aspects of yourself could potentially reignite your motivation and provide a sense of purpose.

2. Seeking professional help: While I'm not a mental health expert, consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor who specializes in depression and existential crises. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you navigate through this difficult phase.

3. Building a support network: Surrounding yourself with supportive individuals can make a significant difference. Consider joining support groups or engaging with communities that align with your interests. Connecting with others who have gone through similar experiences might provide validation and understanding.

4. Engaging in self-care activities: Taking care of your physical and emotional well-being is crucial. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you pleasure or relaxation. Small acts of self-care can gradually improve your overall energy levels.

5. Setting achievable goals: Start by setting small, attainable goals that align with your current state of mind. As you accomplish these goals, celebrate each achievement, no matter how small. This can help rebuild your confidence and create momentum towards larger goals in the future.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to have ups and downs along the way. Be patient with yourself and celebrate any progress you make, no matter how small it may seem. You're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am year old and i finallly came to the conclusion that i need help with anxiety i signed up for therapy and will have my first session in a couple of day prior to the therapy session i met with a prescriber to discus medication they recomended starting me off on zoloft or lexapro in general i tend to think of medication a a last resort not just for thing like this but in all aspect for example i rarely used medinces perscribed to me for pain after surgery and would only use them if absolutely necesarry i don t even like taking ibuprofen for a headache unless it is unbearable given that i am trying to figure out whether or going on anxiety medication is necessary for me or not i am worried about going on something for the rest of my life and am a little concerned about the side effect on the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my anxiety and told myself that since i have been able to graduate from college with a good degree hold down a great job for several year and maintain good relationship that my anxiety must not be that bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long term healthy way of handling this i have also had a couple of concussion in the last few year so i am not sure how much that play into what i am going through i would really appreciate it if some people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've recognized the need for help with your anxiety and are open to therapy. Medication can be a helpful tool, but it's important to consider your own preferences and comfort level. It sounds like you tend to approach medication cautiously, which is completely understandable.

Therapy can definitely be beneficial on its own before considering medication. It allows you to explore and understand your anxiety better, develop coping strategies, and make positive changes in your life. Many people find that therapy alone provides significant relief from their symptoms.

If you decide to pursue medication, it's always a good idea to have an open dialogue with your prescriber about your concerns and any questions you may have. They can provide you with more information about the specific medications they recommended, their potential benefits, and any known side effects. Remember, everyone's experience with medication is unique, so what others have experienced may not necessarily reflect how you will respond.

Considering your history of concussions, it's possible that they could contribute to your current struggles with anxiety. Traumatic brain injuries can indeed impact mood and overall well-being. Exploring this connection further with a healthcare professional might be helpful in gaining a better understanding of how your past experiences are influencing your present situation.

Lastly, if you feel tired all of the time, it's worth discussing this with your therapist or doctor. Chronic fatigue can be a symptom of anxiety, but it can also be related to other factors. Sharing your experience may help them identify any underlying issues that need attention.

Remember, everyone's journey is different, and finding what works best for you may involve some trial and error. Be patient with yourself and trust the process. You've taken an important step by seeking support, and I believe that with therapy and potentially medication, you can find ways to manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
