 It can be challenging to feel like you're on the outside looking in when you're with a group of people. The feeling of not belonging or being abstract from everyone else can be difficult to navigate. It's important to remember that many people experience similar feelings at times, and you are not alone in this.

One suggestion I have is to try focusing on the present moment and engaging with the people around you. Pay attention to what they are saying and show genuine interest in their conversations. By actively participating and listening, you may find common ground with others and feel more connected.

Another idea is to practice self-compassion. Remind yourself that it's okay to have these feelings and that they don't define your worth as a person. Be patient with yourself and give yourself permission to take small steps towards feeling more comfortable in social situations.

Additionally, finding activities or hobbies that align with your interests can provide an opportunity to connect with like-minded individuals. Joining clubs, organizations, or attending events related to your passions can help you meet people who share similar experiences and values.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can offer support and understanding. Sometimes talking about our feelings with someone we trust can provide a fresh perspective and alleviate some of the emotional burden we carry.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to take your time in developing a sense of belonging. You deserve acceptance and friendship, and with patience and self-care, you can work towards feeling more at ease in social situations.

i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out for support and seeking advice on how to navigate through your struggles. It can be challenging when mental health is not openly discussed or addressed in one's upbringing. 

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge and validate the emotions you're experiencing. The intense sadness, internal pain, anger, and rejection you mentioned are all valid feelings. It's understandable that the recent changes in your living situation have triggered these emotions.

When it comes to continuing through life, finding ways to express and process your emotions can be helpful. You mentioned feeling intense inner pain when you were not included in your housemates' dinner plans. One suggestion could be to explore different outlets for self-expression, such as journaling, painting, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment.

Additionally, building a support network can greatly contribute to your well-being. While it may feel daunting to share your struggles with others who may not fully understand, there are various avenues you can explore. Consider joining local community groups or organizations that align with your interests or hobbies. This can provide an opportunity to meet like-minded individuals who might offer understanding and support.

Furthermore, educating yourself about mental health can also be empowering. There are numerous resources available online, including books, articles, and podcasts, that can provide valuable insights and strategies for managing your emotions. Understanding more about mental health can help you gain a sense of control over your experiences and make informed decisions about the help you need.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help from a mental health expert can be beneficial. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. If you decide to pursue this option, ensure you research reputable professionals in your area and reach out to them for an initial consultation.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to take things at your own pace. Be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through this process. You deserve support and understanding, and I believe in your ability to find the help and resources that will benefit you on your path towards healing.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am so tired of having depression i hate how hard it is to get up and do the most basic thing day out of the week i don t even eat dinner because i can t get out of bed i m tired of having to put in the extra effort to hide it at work and in front of my family i ve been single for a year and a half after a year and a half long relationship but my social anxiety ha gotten so bad i can t even put myself out there i m so lonely but too afraid to make an attempt i don t think i could ever actually kill myself but i think about how much easier it would be if i wasn t alive a lot more than i used to

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling tired of having depression and frustrated with the challenges it brings. Depression can make even the simplest tasks feel overwhelming, and I can see how it's affecting your daily routine and relationships.

Feeling tired and unmotivated is a common symptom of depression, and it can be really difficult to find the energy to do things. Skipping meals or not eating dinner because you can't get out of bed is also something many people with depression experience. It's important to take care of yourself physically, even if it feels challenging right now.

Hiding your feelings at work and in front of your family can be emotionally draining. It's completely valid to want to protect yourself from judgment or misunderstanding. However, it's also important to remember that you don't have to face this alone. There are support groups and online communities where you can connect with others who understand what you're going through. Sharing your experiences with people who can relate might provide some comfort and validation.

Social anxiety can make it hard to put yourself out there, especially after a long-term relationship. It's completely normal to feel nervous or afraid to make an attempt, especially when you're already dealing with depression. One step you could take is to start small by reaching out to a trusted friend or family member and sharing how you've been feeling. They may be able to offer support and encouragement as you navigate this difficult time.

While I'm not a mental health professional, it's important to acknowledge the thoughts you mentioned about considering suicide. If you ever feel overwhelmed by these thoughts or believe you may be in immediate danger, please reach out to a helpline or emergency services right away. They are there to provide support and ensure your safety.

Remember, healing takes time, and everyone's journey is unique. It's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. Seeking professional help from a mental health expert can also provide you with additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It sounds like you're experiencing a challenging situation with these anxiety attacks. It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique experiences and emotions, so you're not alone in feeling this way.

One possible step towards understanding and managing your anxiety attacks could be exploring any underlying beliefs or thoughts that may contribute to these reactions. For example, it seems like certain topics trigger intense feelings of defensiveness or fear of being exposed. Reflecting on why these specific subjects bring about such strong reactions might provide some insight into the root cause of your anxiety attacks.

Another helpful strategy could be practicing self-care techniques to help manage anxiety symptoms when they arise. Deep breathing exercises, grounding techniques, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation may assist in calming yourself during moments of anxiety.

Additionally, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or loved one who can offer support and understanding. Sometimes talking about our fears and insecurities with someone we trust can alleviate some of the burden we carry.

In terms of fixing this issue, it's important to recognize that there isn't a quick fix or a one-size-fits-all solution. However, continuing to explore your thoughts, emotions, and triggers can contribute to personal growth and a better understanding of yourself. If you find that your anxiety attacks persist or significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek guidance from a mental health professional who can provide personalized strategies and support.

Remember, you have the strength and resilience to navigate through this experience. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.

i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging when you feel like your anxiety is not responding to medication and you're experiencing worsening symptoms. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that have been helpful for many individuals in managing anxiety attacks.

One technique that you might find beneficial is deep breathing exercises. Taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce feelings of anxiety. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this process several times until you start to feel more calm and centered.

Another strategy that you could explore is grounding techniques. These involve focusing on your senses to bring yourself back to the present moment. For example, you could try noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and connect you with your immediate surroundings.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for stress and anxiety can be incredibly beneficial. Engaging in regular physical exercise, such as going for walks or practicing yoga, can help reduce anxiety symptoms and improve overall well-being. Journaling or expressing yourself creatively through art or music can also provide a sense of relief and release.

Lastly, it may be helpful to reach out to supportive friends or family members who can offer understanding and encouragement during difficult times. Sometimes talking about our feelings with someone we trust can alleviate some of the burden we carry.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and patience. It's essential to work closely with a mental health professional who can tailor treatment specifically to your needs. They can provide additional guidance and support as you navigate this journey towards feeling better.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i feel guilty of everything i feel guilty for telling people my problem and burdening them when they re dealing with worse i feel guilty because when people dump their problem on me i can t handle it anymore it s so selfish of me i hate myself for it so much but when people dump their problem on me i just want to kill myself because i m exhausted i m exhausted of helping people i ve been doing it since i wa 0 and i feel so guilty for being exhausted i cut myself over and over for being so selfish

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling guilty about your emotions and the burden you may have placed on others. It can be challenging when we feel like we're constantly helping others while also dealing with our own struggles. Remember, it's important to prioritize your own well-being and take care of yourself.

Feeling guilty for not being able to handle other people's problems is a common experience, but it's essential to recognize that everyone has limits. You deserve support and understanding just as much as anyone else. Instead of blaming yourself, try to find healthier ways to cope with your exhaustion and frustration.

Self-harm is never an appropriate solution for managing difficult emotions. There are alternative coping strategies you can explore, such as journaling, practicing mindfulness or deep breathing exercises, engaging in creative outlets, or seeking professional help from a therapist who can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, you are not selfish for setting boundaries and prioritizing your own mental health. It's okay to say no when you need to and ask for help yourself. Surrounding yourself with supportive individuals who understand and respect your limits can make a significant difference in how you navigate these feelings of guilt and exhaustion.

Lastly, consider exploring self-care practices that resonate with you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help recharge your energy and improve your overall well-being. This might include hobbies, spending time in nature, connecting with loved ones, or engaging in activities that promote self-reflection and personal growth.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey, and reaching out for support is a courageous step towards healing and finding peace within yourself.

suicidal all weekend watched the infamous funky town gore video i m usually ok with gore and death but that wa horrific made me think could that be me in hell for eternity i mean if human could do something that drawn out and horrific there s no telling what would be in store down there and all because i couldn t handle the cruelty of human nature

Instead of dwelling on these thoughts, perhaps it would be more helpful to focus on finding healthier ways to cope with the cruelty of human nature. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of purpose can help counteract those negative emotions. Remember, nobody is perfect, and we all have moments where we struggle to handle the atrocities committed by humans. It's important to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that it's okay to feel overwhelmed at times. If you find that these thoughts persist or become overwhelming, reaching out to a mental health professional could provide additional guidance and support tailored specifically to your needs.

In the meantime, try to engage in self-care activities that promote relaxation and emotional well-being. This could include practicing mindfulness or deep breathing exercises, engaging in regular physical exercise, getting enough sleep, and maintaining a balanced diet. [Question]
i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging when your mind is constantly filled with thoughts and worries, making it difficult to relax throughout the day. It sounds like you have a lot on your plate and finding the time to truly unwind can be tough.

One suggestion I have is to try incorporating some relaxation techniques into your routine. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery might help calm your mind and allow you to focus on the present moment. You could also consider exploring mindfulness meditation, which involves paying attention to your thoughts and feelings without judgment.

Another idea is to create a designated space for relaxation in your home. This could be a cozy corner with comfortable seating, soft lighting, and soothing music. By creating an environment that feels peaceful and calming, you may find it easier to let go of your anxieties and immerse yourself in activities like reading or watching TV shows.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your energy and anxiety can be beneficial. Engaging in regular physical exercise, such as working out at the gym, can help release tension and promote relaxation. Taking breaks throughout the day to engage in activities you enjoy, even if they're brief, can also provide a much-needed mental reset.

Lastly, it's important to prioritize self-care and give yourself permission to take breaks and relax. Sometimes, our anxious selves push us to constantly pursue productivity and accomplish more, but it's essential to remember that rest and relaxation are just as important for overall well-being.

Remember, everyone's journey towards relaxation is unique, so feel free to experiment with different strategies until you find what works best for you. Keep in mind that progress takes time, and it's okay to have setbacks along the way. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest victories.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i miss my life before this depressive episode idk if you can even call it an episode anymore it s been over year i don t think i ll ever be the same and that destroys me inside i miss 0 9 and 0 0 up until september i wa truly happy and just coasting through life so content i wa so happy and life wa so simple especially during the 0 0 lockdown all i had to do during the lockdown wa watch load of anime and random netflix show explore new music stay up all night and do nothing i even had time to explore my childlike side by doing load of painting and drawing using kiddie paint and colouring book my mental health wa great too i had no eating disorder no depression no school work my anxiety and ocd wa minimal and i wasn t so deeply lonely like i am now i can literally just hear a song smell a smell or taste a good that i experienced to during that period and i will burst out in tear because i miss not being depressed so much now even if i do try and enjoy life like i did back then and be carefree it ll never be the same because my anxiety and depression have quite literally destroyed me from the inside now i ll never be able to enjoy life like that again i had never been in a relationship and that didn t bother me at all now i ve still never been in a relationship and it make me feel unloveable and ugly i always hear people at school talking about their relationship and date and stuff and even though i don t want a boyfriend that bad i still feel like i m missing out on a key part of the teenage experience but still to be honest i m not that keen on a relationship i really just want to be happy anyway all that s left to do is die i have my plan in place and i have a date and method at least i can say that i experienced true happiness and one point in my life i guess

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling a sense of longing for the life you had before this depressive episode. It can be difficult when things change and we lose that sense of happiness and contentment. Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to feel this way.

Instead of focusing on what you think you'll never have again or how your anxiety and depression have affected you, try to focus on the present moment. There may still be opportunities for you to find joy and fulfillment in your life as it is now.

It's important to acknowledge the positive experiences you've had in the past, but also remember that your feelings and needs may have changed over time. It's normal to grow and evolve as individuals. 

While it might be challenging to fully recapture the exact same level of happiness, try exploring new ways to bring positivity into your life. Engaging in activities that bring you even a small amount of joy can make a difference. Consider picking up a hobby or reconnecting with old interests.

Regarding relationships, it's completely valid to not want one at this point in your life. Relationships are personal choices, and there is no "key part" that everyone else gets to experience. Focus on nurturing your own personal growth and self-love instead.

If you're feeling unloveable or ugly because you've never been in a relationship, remember that self-worth shouldn't be determined by external factors like relationships. You are deserving of love and respect just as you are. Surround yourself with supportive friends who appreciate you for who you are.

Lastly, if you have a plan in place and a date set for your method of ending your life, please consider reaching out to a trusted adult or someone who can provide support. They may be able to help you explore alternative options and provide assistance during this difficult time. Remember, there is always hope for healing and finding a reason to live.

Take care of yourself and remember that you are not alone.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hi i am male i used to have a very emotional side but for the last year or so i am not able to feel sad especially for others sympathy i used to cry when my best friend cried to me about her break up but now i couldn t shed a single tear during my grandfather death i hated the feeling did i stop loving my grandfather even then why didn t i feel sad when i saw my mother cry she is the first person i don t want to see cry off late i feel it s affecting my friendship a well just to be clear it s not a overall numbness i still feel happiness anger and other emotion but this is really frustrating especially when i am getting into a relationship for the first time in my life i keep questioning my love for people i keep asking myself if i can t feel sad for them do i really love them

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and concerned about your ability to feel sad. It seems like you used to have a strong emotional side, but recently you've noticed a change in how you respond to certain situations. Specifically, you mentioned not being able to cry when your best friend cried about her breakup or during your grandfather's death.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone experiences emotions differently, and there is no right or wrong way to grieve or express sadness. Your feelings are valid, even if they don't align with what you expect or what others around you are experiencing.

That being said, it may be helpful to explore any underlying reasons behind this shift in your emotional responses. Sometimes, significant life events or changes in our own lives can impact how we relate to the emotions of others. Reflecting on any recent major life transitions, such as starting a new job or ending a long-term friendship, could provide some insight into why you might be feeling differently now.

Additionally, consider examining any past experiences that may have influenced how you perceive sadness or vulnerability. Sometimes, our upbringing or other formative experiences shape our emotional responses. Exploring these factors with self-reflection or journaling might help shed light on any possible connections.

While it's natural to question your love for people when you're not able to feel sad for them, it's essential to recognize that emotions can be complex and nuanced. Loving someone doesn't always manifest in the same way, and it doesn't mean that your feelings aren't genuine.

Instead of focusing solely on your ability to feel sad, try to broaden your perspective and appreciate the range of emotions you do experience. Happiness, anger, and other positive emotions are valuable parts of being human too.

If you find that this shift in your emotional responses is negatively impacting your relationships or overall well-being, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and help you navigate these emotions.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to seek support when needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve been on venlafaxine for year or so it helped at first but it hasn t helped whatsoever in quite some time i take 0mg in the morning the last month my anxiety and panic ha been absolutely crippling debilitating and unbearable i called the dr today and he called in a prescription to increase me from 0mg to mg i hate taking any medication or pill whatsoever especially increasing a dosage anyone had any good result from a venlafaxine increase after taking the same dosage for such a long time

Increasing the dosage of Venlafaxine can sometimes be helpful in managing these symptoms, so it's worth giving it a try. It's important to remember that everyone responds differently to medications, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, many individuals have reported positive results after increasing their Venlafaxine dosage, even if they have been taking the same dosage for a long time.

When increasing the dosage of any medication, it is crucial to follow your doctor's instructions carefully. They will likely monitor your progress closely and adjust the dosage as needed. Remember that it may take some time for your body to adapt to the increased dosage, and you may experience some side effects during this period. It would be best to discuss any concerns or questions you have with your doctor before starting the new dosage.

In addition to taking medication, there are also other strategies you can try to help manage your anxiety and panic symptoms. Deep breathing exercises, mindfulness techniques, regular exercise, and practicing self-care activities like getting enough sleep and maintaining a balanced diet can all contribute to improving your overall well-being.

Remember, everyone's journey with mental health is unique, and finding the right combination of treatments and coping mechanisms can take time. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, consider reaching out to a support group or a trusted friend or family member who can provide emotional support.

Take care, and I hope you find relief from your anxiety and panic symptoms soon.

 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and hopeless about your situation. It can be really challenging when depression persists despite trying various treatments and therapies. I want to acknowledge the strength and courage it takes to reach out and share your feelings.

While I may not have all the answers, I want you to know that there are people who care and want to support you through this difficult time. It's important to remember that everyone's journey with depression is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that have been helpful for many individuals in managing their symptoms:

1. Self-Care: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. This could include engaging in activities that bring you joy, practicing relaxation techniques, getting enough sleep, and maintaining a balanced diet.

2. Support Network: Surrounding yourself with understanding and supportive individuals can make a significant difference. Consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support during challenging times.

3. Mindfulness and Meditation: Incorporating mindfulness and meditation practices into your daily routine can help reduce stress and increase overall well-being. These practices can also assist in grounding yourself during moments of overwhelming emotions.

4. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal can be therapeutic and provide a sense of release. It can also help identify patterns or triggers that contribute to your depressive symptoms.

5. Seeking Professional Help: While you mentioned that you've tried various medical treatments and therapies without improvement, it might be worth exploring different approaches or speaking with a mental health professional who can offer personalized guidance and support.

Remember, healing takes time, and progress may come in small steps. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. You deserve support and understanding, even if it feels like you're facing this alone. If you ever need someone to talk to, please don't hesitate to reach out.

i know that sound weird but i wa talking to my therapist yesterday about how i usually don t realize i am in a bad place until i am out of it and look back at that time long story short we talked about getting better at recognizing it and today i have been feeling really down and sluggish and angry wa i depressed yesterday but just didn t realize it not sure if this ramble make sense but yeah i thought i wa fine yesterday now i am not even though nothing in my life changed

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're working with a therapist to improve your ability to recognize when you're in a bad place. It can be challenging to identify our emotions in the moment, but looking back on them later can provide valuable insights. From what you've shared, it seems like today you are experiencing feelings of sadness, sluggishness, and anger, which may indicate that you are going through a difficult time.

One suggestion I have is to try keeping a journal or some kind of record where you can jot down your thoughts and feelings throughout the day. This can help you notice patterns or recurring themes that might not be immediately apparent. Additionally, paying attention to any physical sensations or changes in your energy levels could also provide clues about your emotional state.

Another strategy you could explore is practicing mindfulness or grounding techniques. These involve focusing on the present moment and engaging your senses to bring yourself back to reality. Deep breathing exercises, guided imagery, or engaging in activities that promote relaxation, such as listening to calming music or taking a walk in nature, can also be helpful in managing distressing emotions.

Lastly, it might be beneficial to discuss these experiences with your therapist during your next session. They can provide personalized guidance and support based on their expertise and knowledge of your unique situation. Remember, progress takes time, so be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you as you continue on your journey towards better emotional recognition and overall well-being.

a the title say i can t be bothered with life anymore it taking me so long to even go to a bridge and jump off i just wan na die already got no friend family dont give a crap amp i always get left behind when it come to meeting people so why not end it all and be done with this pain

Online communities or local clubs/groups could provide an opportunity to meet new people and potentially form connections that could support you during this time. Another option worth exploring is seeking professional help from a mental health therapist. They can provide a safe space for you to express your feelings and work through any underlying issues contributing to your desire to end your life. Therapy can equip you with coping strategies and tools to navigate through difficult emotions.

Lastly, it might also be helpful to engage in self-care activities that bring you comfort and joy. This could include things like practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in creative outlets such as art or writing, or taking walks in nature. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can make a significant difference in how you feel overall.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. There are resources available to support you, and it's important to reach out and utilize them. You deserve to live a life that brings you happiness and fulfillment, even if it feels out of reach right now.

[Question]
i ll go first i got rejected recently it happens a lot to me it s my th time now i can t stop being anxious abt it it sickens me thinking abt it and idek why i m still anxious abt it i also have bipolar disorder so that make thing even better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really tough to deal with rejection, especially when it happens multiple times. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious about it and finding it difficult to stop thinking about it. Having bipolar disorder adds an extra layer of challenge to this situation.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing self-compassion. Remind yourself that rejection is a normal part of life and that it doesn't define your worth as a person. Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would support a friend who is going through a similar experience.

Another strategy that might help is focusing on building resilience. Instead of dwelling on past rejections, try to shift your mindset towards learning from these experiences. Ask yourself what you can do differently next time to increase your chances of success. This approach can give you a sense of control and empowerment.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your emotions can be beneficial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time with loved ones, can help distract from negative thoughts and reduce anxiety.

Consider reaching out to a support system, whether it's friends, family, or even online communities, who can provide encouragement and validation during difficult times. Sometimes talking to someone who understands what you're going through can make a big difference.

Lastly, if you find that your anxiety around rejection continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be helpful to seek professional guidance from a mental health expert. They can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, healing takes time, and everyone's journey is unique. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve compassion, understanding, and support as you navigate through this challenging experience.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out to your psych and doing research to find what might work for you. Panic attacks can be really challenging, but there are strategies and techniques that may help manage them. Constant anxiety can also be overwhelming, but there are ways to cope with it.

Given the information you've shared, it seems like your panic attacks vary in intensity. Frequent mild panic attacks can sometimes go unnoticed or be mistaken for other feelings. On the other hand, severe panic attacks can be quite distressing. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another.

You mentioned trying various anxiety meds without finding any that worked for you. It's worth noting that medication is just one option among many when it comes to managing anxiety. While medications can be helpful for some individuals, they may not be the right fit for everyone. Consider discussing your specific situation with your psych, as they can provide personalized guidance based on your medical history and current needs.

In addition to medication, there are other approaches you can explore. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has shown effectiveness in treating anxiety and panic disorders. CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and developing healthier coping mechanisms. You might want to discuss this with your psych, as they can provide more information about CBT and potentially recommend resources or exercises you can try on your own.

Mindfulness practices, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, can also be beneficial in reducing anxiety symptoms. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, like hobbies or spending time in nature, can help alleviate anxiety as well.

Remember, finding the right approach takes time and patience. It's important to communicate openly with your psych about your experiences and any concerns you may have. They can guide you through this process and offer support along the way.

Thank you for reaching out, and I hope these suggestions provide some guidance as you continue your journey towards managing your anxiety and panic attacks.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
it s been so long i have been avoiding to get treated especially because it s social anxiety i definitely don t want to talk to a stranger but it s been ruining my life so here we are any tip anything i should prepare what question do they ask you i am already getting anxiety attack because of the appointment

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out for help, even though it may feel challenging due to your social anxiety. Remember that therapists are trained professionals who are there to support you, and they won't judge you or treat you any differently than anyone else.

To prepare for your appointment, it might be helpful to think about some things you could discuss with the therapist. Reflecting on your experiences with social anxiety and how it has affected your life can provide valuable insights. You could also consider any specific situations or triggers that tend to provoke anxiety for you.

When it comes to questions they ask, therapists typically start by getting to know you and understanding your background. They might ask about your personal history, relationships, and any previous experiences with therapy. These questions are designed to build a foundation of trust and understanding between you and your therapist.

Remember, therapy is a collaborative process, so don't hesitate to communicate your concerns and preferences to your therapist. Letting them know about your anxiety around certain topics can help guide the conversation and ensure your comfort.

To manage your anxiety leading up to the appointment, there are a few strategies you can try. Deep breathing exercises, such as taking slow breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth, can help calm your nervous system. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, like listening to calming music or going for a walk, can also help reduce anxiety.

Additionally, practicing self-compassion can be beneficial. Remind yourself that seeking support is a courageous step towards improving your well-being. Be patient with yourself and allow room for growth throughout the therapeutic process.

Remember, your therapist is there to support you, and together you can work towards managing your social anxiety and improving your overall quality of life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i am not sure if this is possible and i appreciate any information a few year ago i wa diagnosed with clinical anxiety depression and adhd i wa relieved and terrified and so sad it took me until adulthood to learn this about myself i began medicating under the direction of my psychiatrist after about a year i changed from zoloft to prozac due to weight gain i began experiencing night sweat for the first time in my life about month ago it wa sporadic for month or so than became nightly now it ha worsened to the point that i wake up multiple time a night to change sheet and pajama i m not wetting the bed but truly soaking it through with my sweat in a degree room with minimal blanket i ve had to replace plastic bed protector mattress cover and even my mattress i believe i am having panic attack while i am asleep and i am unable to remember them assuming i would remember having a nightmare at the same time or be semi lucid what could paralyze me in sleep while having normal pleasant dream and cause excessive night sweat my change in medication did not correlate with the onset or increase in the night sweat i have had blood test mri pulmonary exam allergy test ultra sound and more no western doctor or my psychiatrist ha been able to find anything unusual that would explain the night sweat tl dr extreme night sweat begin in adulthood with no obvious cause desperately looking for advice on what might help edit 9 f

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling concerned about your night sweats and the impact it's having on your sleep. It can be frustrating when there doesn't seem to be an obvious cause for this issue. While I'm not a medical professional, I can offer some suggestions that may help you address this concern.

Firstly, it might be helpful to communicate your experiences with your psychiatrist. They have been involved in your treatment journey and have knowledge of your specific condition. Sharing your concerns about the night sweats could lead to a more comprehensive discussion about potential underlying factors contributing to this symptom.

Additionally, exploring relaxation techniques or mindfulness exercises before bedtime might assist in managing anxiety-related symptoms while you sleep. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery are examples of practices that could help promote a sense of calmness and reduce the intensity of any potential panic attacks during sleep.

Another suggestion is to evaluate your current medication regimen. Although you mentioned that changing from Zoloft to Prozac did not correlate with the onset or increase of night sweats, it's always worth discussing any medication-related concerns with your prescribing psychiatrist. They can provide insights into possible interactions or side effects that may be influencing your symptoms.

In terms of managing the excessive sweating during the night, you could consider using a specialized mattress pad designed to absorb moisture. These pads are available in most bedding stores and can help prevent the need to constantly change sheets and pajamas throughout the night.

Lastly, keeping a sleep diary might provide valuable insights into any patterns or triggers related to your night sweats. By noting down your daily activities, emotions, and any factors that stand out before bedtime, you may identify certain patterns or circumstances that contribute to the intensity of your symptoms. This information can then be discussed with your psychiatrist to further refine your treatment plan.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to have open communication with your healthcare providers and advocate for your own well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

guy do any of you also wake up every morning from scary nightmare and feeling completely estranged when you open your eye like your surrounding feel so foreign eventho it s your own home your own room and it take some time for you to realize youre just fine do you wake up with fear every morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really unsettling to wake up from a scary nightmare and feel disconnected from your surroundings. It's understandable that it takes some time for you to realize that you're okay and back in your own space. This experience is actually quite common, and many people go through similar moments when they first open their eyes in the morning.

One suggestion I have is to try incorporating some relaxation techniques into your morning routine. Deep breathing exercises or gentle stretching can help calm your mind and body after waking up. Additionally, taking a moment to ground yourself by focusing on your senses - noticing the things you can see, hear, touch, taste, and smell in your immediate environment - can also help bring you back into the present moment.

Another idea is to keep a journal by your bedside. Before getting out of bed, you could spend a few minutes writing down any recurring dreams or feelings you remember from your night. This practice might provide some insights into patterns or themes that could be helpful to explore further.

Engaging in activities that promote self-care and reduce anxiety throughout the day could also be beneficial. This could include things like practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in hobbies or activities that bring you joy, or seeking support from loved ones when needed.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It might be helpful to experiment with different strategies and see what resonates with you. If these feelings persist or become overwhelming, it could be valuable to reach out to a mental health professional who can offer additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

[Question]
i ve been experiencing huge bout of just feeling unmotivated not useful i ve been randomly just tearing up but it never last long i don t feel like i have a reason to cry but i do and i don t know what to do there s other stuff but i don t want to drag on too long i also just miss how thing were i ve woken up like this for the past week and it s persisted throughout the day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a difficult time lately, experiencing feelings of unmotivation and sadness. It's important to acknowledge and address these emotions in a healthy way. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Take small steps towards self-care: Start by focusing on yourself and your well-being. Engage in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment, even if they seem insignificant at first. This could be as simple as taking a walk outside, reading a book, or trying out a new hobby.

2. Reach out for support: Consider talking to someone you trust about what you've been going through. Sharing your feelings with a friend or family member can offer comfort and understanding. Sometimes, just having someone listen without judgment can make a big difference.

3. Explore your emotions: Reflect on why you might be feeling unmotivated and tearful without a clear reason. It's not uncommon for emotions to surface without an obvious cause. Journaling or engaging in creative outlets like art or music can help you explore and understand your emotions better.

4. Establish a routine: Having a structured daily routine can provide a sense of stability and purpose. Try setting small goals for yourself each day and gradually increase them over time. Celebrate your achievements, no matter how small they may seem.

5. Prioritize self-compassion: Be kind to yourself during this challenging period. Remember that it's okay to have ups and downs, and progress takes time. Treat yourself with patience, understanding, and compassion. Practice self-compassionate affirmations or engage in activities that promote self-acceptance and self-love.

6. Seek professional guidance if needed: If your symptoms persist or worsen, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional support and guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can help you navigate through these emotions and develop coping strategies.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself. You deserve support and understanding as you work through these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling the need to protect yourself from overwhelming emotions. It can be challenging when we carry around painful experiences and it's important to find healthy ways to cope. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that may help guide you:

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your emotions and identify any patterns or triggers that may contribute to your emotional shutdown. Understanding what causes these feelings can provide valuable insights into why you react the way you do.

2. Seek support: Consider reaching out to a trusted friend, family member, or even a therapist who can provide a safe space for you to express your emotions. Talking about your feelings with someone who understands can be incredibly healing.

3. Mindfulness techniques: Practice mindfulness exercises such as deep breathing, meditation, or grounding techniques. These practices can help you stay present in the moment and manage your emotions more effectively.

4. Healthy outlets: Engage in activities that bring you joy and allow you to express yourself. This could include hobbies, art, exercise, or any other creative outlet that helps you release pent-up emotions.

5. Journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal can be a helpful tool for processing emotions. It provides an opportunity to explore your experiences without judgment and gain clarity on your emotions.

6. Professional guidance: If you feel comfortable, consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist. They can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's important to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve to experience emotional well-being and find healthy ways to navigate your emotions.

One possible approach could be exploring different coping mechanisms when you start feeling overwhelmed. Engaging in activities that bring you comfort or provide an outlet for your emotions, such as journaling, painting, or exercising, may help alleviate some of the distress you're experiencing.

Additionally, finding healthy ways to express yourself and talking to someone you trust about what you're going through can make a big difference. This might include friends, family members, or even support groups where you can connect with others who have had similar experiences. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone who understands can provide validation and support.

Another suggestion is practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment without judgment. It can help you become more aware of your thoughts and feelings, allowing you to observe them without getting caught up in them. There are various resources available, such as guided meditation apps or online videos, that can guide you through mindfulness exercises.

Lastly, if you haven't already, consider reaching out to a mental health hotline or organization. They can provide immediate support and connect you with professionals who can offer additional guidance tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find the strategies that work best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve support and understanding, and I believe in your ability to navigate through this challenging period.

[Question]
i have gad and have been going through an emotional upheaval with my partner causing extra stress i ve been reducing my lexapro slightly a i felt it wa not working but now am more anxious than ever despite tiny change today i woke up full of dread to go to work no reason i love my job but it all felt too much a a mid ground i decided to work from home today instead of going in i still feel light headed and awful and have the added guilt of messing client around by changing the schedule or converting to online service what do i do how do i get myself to work when it all feel too much

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed with the emotional upheaval and stress from your partner, as well as the changes you've made to your medication. It can be challenging when anxiety increases despite a slight reduction in Lexapro.

Today, it seems like waking up with dread and feeling lightheaded are affecting your ability to go to work. It's important to prioritize your mental health and find ways to manage these feelings. Here are some suggestions:

1. Communicate with your partner: Consider having an open and honest conversation about how their actions are impacting your mental well-being. Effective communication can help address conflicts and reduce stress.

2. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or trusted individuals who can provide emotional support during this difficult time. Sometimes talking to someone outside the situation can offer a fresh perspective.

3. Self-care routine: Establish a self-care routine that includes activities that promote relaxation and reduce anxiety. This could include practicing deep breathing exercises, engaging in hobbies you enjoy, taking breaks throughout the day, or trying mindfulness techniques.

4. Gradual adjustments: If you feel comfortable, you can try gradually adjusting your medication dosage instead of making significant changes all at once. Consult with a healthcare professional to discuss what is safe and appropriate for you.

5. Explore therapy options: Therapy can provide a safe space for you to process your emotions, gain coping strategies, and work through any challenges you may be facing. Look into different therapy modalities such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), or online counseling services.

6. Create a supportive work environment: Since you mentioned working from home today, ensure that your workspace is comfortable and conducive to productivity. Set boundaries with others at home, communicate your needs, and create a schedule that allows for breaks and self-care.

7. Break tasks into manageable steps: Instead of focusing on the entire workday, break it down into smaller, achievable tasks. Celebrate each step you complete, as this can help build momentum and alleviate some of the pressure.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself during this process. If you continue to struggle with these feelings, reach out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m slipping into a deep deep depression divorce failed business losing my home many regret etc etc i need a direction in my life i can focus and work hard on but i don t even know where to begin i need someone to help me a there s no way i can do it myself i have adhd so my mind go in a million direction all the time is a good life coach what i need

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and lost right now. Going through a divorce, failing in business, and losing your home are all significant challenges that can take a toll on your mental well-being. It's important to acknowledge the emotions that come with these experiences.

Finding direction in life can be a journey, but it's definitely possible for you. One suggestion is to start by reflecting on your strengths and interests. What are some activities or hobbies that bring you joy or make you feel accomplished? Identifying those areas could help you gain clarity on potential paths to explore.

Additionally, consider reaching out to supportive friends or family members who may be able to offer guidance or even just lend an ear. Sometimes talking through our thoughts and feelings with someone we trust can provide valuable insights and support.

Since you mentioned having ADHD, it might be helpful to explore strategies and techniques that can assist you in focusing your mind. Breaking tasks into smaller, manageable steps and creating a structured routine can be beneficial. You may also want to research different productivity apps or tools that can aid in organizing your thoughts and keeping you on track.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help from a life coach or therapist can be incredibly valuable. They are trained to assist individuals like yourself in navigating difficult times and finding purpose. Their expertise can provide you with additional support and guidance tailored specifically to your needs.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to take your time in figuring out what direction you want to go. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve support and the opportunity to create a fulfilling life for yourself.

in high school i wa quiet mind my business didn t talk to many people i noticed that certain people just didn t like me one time a teacher moved a girl to sit next to me and she made this weird face like annoyed and when she sat next to me she wa slightly turned ti the direction i wasn t in and not facing straight another occasion i wa sitting in a table with other people and none of them would bother to talk to me even when i tried to make a convo or ask a question and one of them actually cut hair now and my brother and dad cut their hair with her and they re always saying she talk a lot etc she s friendly today i went to that place to cut my hair and she wa completely quiet just asked me what hair type i wanted and the price of the cut i didn t want to start a convo cause i knew that back then she wouldn t even want to talk i just feel like i have something that just make people dislike me for no reason

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've had some experiences in high school where you felt a lack of connection with others and noticed that certain people didn't seem to like you. It can be frustrating when we try to initiate conversations or ask questions, but others don't respond or show interest.

One incident that stood out to you was when a teacher moved a girl to sit next to you, and she made a face of annoyance. This may have made you feel uncomfortable or wondered why she reacted that way. Additionally, when you were sitting with other people, they didn't engage in conversation or even acknowledge your presence, which could leave you feeling isolated.

More recently, you mentioned going to get your hair cut at a place where one of the girls who used to interact with you worked. During this visit, she was quiet and didn't initiate conversation, unlike how she is now, according to your brother and dad. You mentioned feeling something different about yourself, suggesting that there might be something about you that causes others to dislike you without any clear reason.

While it's unhelpful to jump to conclusions about why people behave the way they do, it's understandable that these experiences have left you feeling unsure of yourself and wondering what sets you apart from others. It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique qualities and strengths, and it's not always easy to understand why certain individuals connect differently with us.

One suggestion I have is to focus on self-acceptance and self-confidence. Embrace who you are and recognize your own worth. Building a positive relationship with yourself can help boost your self-esteem and make it easier to connect with others.

Another idea is to explore activities or hobbies that genuinely interest you. Engaging in things you enjoy can provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals who share similar interests, making it easier to form connections.

Lastly, consider reaching out to supportive friends or family members who can offer encouragement and guidance as you navigate these social situations. Sometimes having someone by your side can make it easier to initiate conversations and build relationships.

Remember, forming connections with others takes time and effort, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. You deserve to have fulfilling relationships, and by focusing on self-acceptance, pursuing your interests, and seeking support from those around you, you may find that your interactions with others improve over time.

i can t find the strength to do anything i m supposed to do like studying going to the gym or finding a job i have been losing interest in thing i used to like to the point i don t enjoy doing them and they are becoming difficult to do because they are supposed to make me happy and being happy requires a lot of energy i don t have by losing interest and thing i like i m running thin of thing that keep me motivated for living and hope for the future i have difficulty getting help because i don t think it is worth the effort for a hopeless person like me i don t even think i deserve that help considering the thing i hate about myself i don t even want to talk about this thing with other people that care for me because with my point of view of the world and future might grab them down to this dark and hopeless vision the only thing that keep me from km is that i know it would hurt people around me i really need something to look forward something that give me the motivation to keep going

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really tough to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and support.

Firstly, it's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people experience periods of low motivation and struggle to find the energy to do things they used to enjoy. It's completely understandable that losing interest in these activities has made them more challenging for you.

One suggestion I have is to start small. Instead of focusing on studying, going to the gym, or finding a job all at once, try breaking those tasks down into smaller, manageable steps. For example, if studying feels overwhelming, try setting aside just 10 minutes each day to review your notes or read a chapter. Gradually increase the time as you start feeling more motivated.

[Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and sharing your experience with anxiety and panic. It can be challenging when our worries seem to shift from one thing to another, but there are strategies that may help break this cycle.

One approach you could consider is practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment without judgment. By bringing your attention to the here and now, you may find it easier to let go of anxious thoughts about the past or future. There are various mindfulness exercises you can try, such as deep breathing, body scans, or guided meditation.

Another strategy that might be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. By examining the evidence for and against your worries, you can gain a more balanced perspective. Additionally, CBT often involves setting goals and gradually exposing yourself to situations that trigger anxiety, which can help desensitize you over time.

In terms of stopping the cycle, it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique. However, finding healthy coping mechanisms that work for you can make a significant difference. Engaging in activities you enjoy, like hobbies or exercise, can provide a positive outlet for stress and anxiety. Connecting with supportive friends or loved ones can also offer comfort and understanding.

Lastly, I encourage you to continue attending therapy and taking your prescribed medications as recommended by your healthcare provider. Therapy can provide ongoing support and guidance tailored to your specific needs, while medications can help manage symptoms.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. You've already taken an important step by seeking support, and I believe in your ability to navigate through this journey of healing and growth.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
tw depression okay besties i need some help opinion ab my struggle with brushing my hair i currently have really bad knot in my hair and i m hispanic white and my hair is so thick and curly i don t understand how to properly take care of it and i haven t brushed my hair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging to manage thick and curly hair, especially when it's tangled. Here are some suggestions that might help you with your struggle:

1. Start by detangling your hair before brushing. You can try using a wide-tooth comb or your fingers to gently loosen any knots or tangles. This step can make brushing easier and less painful.

2. Consider using a leave-in conditioner or detangler spray on your hair before brushing. These products can help soften and moisturize your curls, making them easier to manage.

3. Take small sections of your hair and gently brush from the ends upwards. Focus on one section at a time to avoid overwhelming yourself. Be patient and take your time, as rushing can increase frustration and potential damage to your hair.

4. If you find it difficult to brush through the knots, you may want to try finger-combing instead. Use your fingers to gently work through the tangles, starting from the ends and working your way towards the roots. This method can be less painful and more forgiving for thick and curly hair.

5. After brushing, consider styling your hair in a protective style, such as a braid or bun. Protective styles can help protect your hair from further tangling and breakage.

6. Remember to be kind to yourself throughout this process. It's okay if it takes time and effort to figure out what works best for you and your hair type. Experiment with different techniques and products until you find what suits you.

7. Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to friends or family members who have experience with similar hair types. They may have valuable insights or recommendations that could benefit you on your journey towards proper hair care.

Remember, taking care of your hair is a personal journey, and what works for others may not always work for you. Be patient with yourself, celebrate small victories, and keep trying different approaches until you find what feels right for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
